text:
As already mentioned before in the reviews, the measurements on this recipe are a little off. If baked as per recipe, the quiche will be too oily and will not fit into one deep pie dish.  Instead, I suggest making 2 quiches!  Keep the same amount of spinach/mushroom/cheese mixture and separate it into 2 portions.  Use the 4 eggs and 1 cup of milk (can decrease to 3/4 if you like) and half of the spinach/mushroom/cheese mixture for one quiche, and the same for the other quiche.  Only use 1 tbsp of butter instead of the 1/2 cup recommended as it is WAY too much butter if you stick to the recipe.
The quiches turned out delicious and had a beautiful colour to them! Since this was my first quiche, I was afraid it would be too watery, but it came out firm.  Tastes great!

text:
As many reviewers noted, this is a very forgiving recipe. I used some olive oil while cooking down fresh spinach and therefore no butter, 1/2 cup milk, and less chedder cheese.  It turned out great!!!!!  I recommend putting empty pie crust in oven for 5-7 min prior to filling to give it a crispy bottom crust  - no more soggy bottom!!

text:
Why oh why can't there be a six star rating?  Let me preface this by saying that I have never been a big fan of quiche.  I told my husband I'd make one, so I found this recipe.  This is not only the BEST quiche I have ever had; I'd venture to say it is one of the most delicious foods I've ever eaten.  Next time, I will try to make it with less butter as others have suggested.  I used plain feta and added a dash of oregano, basil, rosemary and seasoned pepper.  I made the Pastry for a Single Crust Pie from this site, and it was great for this dish.  (Probably not so great for a sweet pie).  Anyway, thank you for the fantastic recipe Bailey, you are single-handedly responsible for finding a way to get my six year old to not only EAT spinach, but to eat it with gusto!  I am in your debt.  :)

Edited to add:  If you ever plan on making this "healthier" by cutting back on the butter, I highly recommend you do it the FIRST time, so you won't be disappointed in the difference.  It's still a good quiche with 1.5 Tbsp of butter, but it's a GREAT quiche with the whole stick.  LOL

text:
I made a few changes only because I was looking for a particular recipe that I couldn't find...I used swiss cheese instead of cheddar...left out the mushrooms (because I don't like them) used 1 heaping Tablespoon of margarine (instead of the 1/2 cup butter) eggbeaters for the eggs and skim milk and this was Fantastic.  I served it along with other things at a brunch and this dish was gone in 10 minutes..When I make it again (and I will) I will make 2 or 3 of them! I made this the day before, refrigerated it overnight and then warmed it in the oven the morning of the brunch (covered in foil to prevent overbrowning) It reheated perfectly.

text:
This was great!  I made a few variations to lower the fat content.

I used margarine instead of butter and halved it, per everyone's suggestions.  I used skim milk, and I used egg whites instead of eggs.  I also reduced the cheddar a bit. And it was still great!  I can only imagine how wonderful it would be if I used all the real ingredients instead of the low-fat stuff.

Also, I used fresh mushrooms and sauted them with the onions and garlic.  Veeeery yummy.  I made mine without a pie shell.  Other fun things to try next time include bacon bits, a handful of almonds or pecans, raisins, or topping it with bread crumbs, croutons or fried onions!  There are just too many fun things to do with this recipe, so I'll definately be making it again.  And again.  And again.  And... ;)

Thank you so much!  Okay, I'll shut up now.  :D

text:
The flavor blends in this spinch-feta-garlic quiche were very tasty. Follwing the advice of others I decreased the butter from 1/2 c to 6T.....it was still too greasy. Next time I will reduce it to 3T or maybe use a little olive oil. I will also omit the salt altogether. Every family member mentioned how salty it was. Feta and cheddar make it salty enough. I used fresh baby spinach steamed instead of frozen. I think with these changes the flavor blends will have a chance to blossom.

text:
WOW.  This was so excellent.  I made it for my Bridesmaid's Luncheon and everyone loved it.  I should, however, have read the reviews first and not used as much butter-- maybe only 1/2 or 2/3 as much.  I would call this less of a quiche and more like the Greek dish Spanikopita (spinach pie).  I left the mushrooms out and just used the spinach and the cheese.  The extra butter made the pie crust nice and flaky (in some spots-- in others is was just soggy and greasy) like the phillo dough used in Spanikopita.  I used Sundried Tomato and Basil Feta (all I could find) and it was delicious.  The cheddar cheese and egg on top were a very pleasant contrast to the spinach and feta mixture on the bottom.  A past reviewer said her egg mixture overflowed in the oven, even though she used a deep dish pie crust.  Maybe that was because you used eggs that were too large?  I don't think I'd use anything bigger than a large egg for this recipe.  Also, I think a cup of milk is too much to add to the eggs.  I only used between 1/2 and 3/4 of a cup.  This turned out way better than I expected.  It's also one of those great dishes you can get creative with depending on your mood.  Just change the ingredients to whatever you have on hand or feel like using!  A++

text:
SOOOO good!  The changes I made were to use half of the recommended butter, sauteed fresh mushrooms with the onions, and added some minced sun-dried tomatoes to the spinach.  I used 2 9” regular pie crusts (instead of 1 deep dish) and it was the perfect amount for 2 quiches.  I baked the pie crust for about 5 min before I added the spinach so it wouldn’t get soggy.  I also added a dash of Italian seasoning to the feta because I could only find regular.  It was FANTASTIC!!  *UPDATE*  I minced a few fresh basil leaves into the spinach.  It was a whole new level of delicious!

text:
I just returned from a PTA sponsored breakfast for the teacher's because today is national teacher's day and I was asked to help out and make a quiche.  I usually do not make something to bring somewhere without having made it before but I figured with all the positive reviews of this quiche, I couldn't go wrong.  This is a TEN star recipe.  There were five quiches at the teacher breakfast and this one was gone in 15 minutes.  Teachers were asking me for the recipe! I only used half a stick of butter and half the package of spinach, I just feel that the whole 10 oz package of spinach is too much. Other than those minor changes, I followed the recipe exactly.  The garlic-herb feta gives it a wonderful flavor.  I have also made the crustles spinach quiche on this website and this one is really much, much tastier and delicious.  I can't want to make it again.  Thanks for a superb recipe!!

text:
Also made a couple changes, but an excellent quiche resulted, so that's what counts! Combined this recipe with "Suzanne's Spinach Quiche" for a winner. ...Combine 6 strips crumbled bacon, 9oz. fresh spinach (wilted), browned onions & garlic in a 9"crust; top with 1c. cheddar; mix 3 eggs, 1c. yogurt, salt & pepper - pour over spinach; bake 15 min.; top with remaining cheddar; bake 30 min. till done.  YUMMY!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is excellent!  And a must try for anyone who's never made quiche before or is looking for an awesome recipe as is or to work with.  It's very simple and excellent.  Personally, my fiance and I hate onions, so I skipped that.  I cooked the pie crust for approx. 10 minutes by itself.  I put 4 oz. of the cheddar cheese in the quiche and used a smidge less than 1 cup milk (the first time it overflowed).  I cooked only the garlic, spinach and mushrooms in 2 1/2 T. butter (you don't want it too greasy), and set them aside to cool.  Mixed everything else (including cheeses, I did this because the cheese melted as per the instructions the first time I made it making it difficult to mix the ingredents for the oven) then added the cooled cooked mixture and poured into the pie crust.  I cooked for 40 minutes. Then added 2 oz. cheddar cheese to the top plus approx. 6-8 pieces broken apart cooked bacon.  Cook for another 10-15 minutes.  For newbies: don't forget to cover the outside of the crust with tinfoil to prevent burning.  A wonderful recipe that you can easily modify to suit your own taste!

text:
What a fantastic recipe this is!  I took the advise of others and cut the butter back to 1/4 cup.  Also, I could only find plain feta cheese so I added a dash of garlic powder, basil, oregano and thyme.  I used a 9" unbaked deep dish pie crust as directed in the recipe.  However, I removed it from the aluminum pan and placed it in a ceramic deep-dish quiche dish.  This solved the problem some readers had with overflow and it gives the appearance that the crust was "homemade" too.  The quiche turned out picture perfect and was absolutely the best I've ever had.  Thank you for wonderful recipe!

text:
This recipe is definitely VERY forgiving.....first time I ever prepared quiche.  I used cream cheese instead of feta, monterey pepper jack instead of cheddar, cream instead of milk, and omitted the mushrooms.  I made substitutions because I already had on hand the mentioned ingredients.  I had more than I needed for a 9 inch pie crust so I put the remaining mixture in a non-stick pan.  So, this recipe lends itself nicely to a non-crust quiche as well.

text:
Wonderful dish! If you want to prepare it ahead of time, you can mix all of the filling ingredients together in a bowl and refrigerate overnight. In the morning pour into your pieshell and bake. Presto! Very easy for an early morning meal and it tastes just as great! I added bacon to my quiche and used 6 eggs instead of 4 as others suggested. This was perfect to fill a 9-inch deep dish ready-made crust. I also found that no extra salt was needed--the feta and cheddar gives it plenty of flavor! Loved it!!!!

text:
This recipe was so easy to make and tasted so good.  I made it last night for my boyfriend and he loved it.  I took the advice of some other reviewers as follows:  1) reduced the butter to 1 heaping tablespoon, 2) reduced the amount of milk to 2/3 cup, and 3) baked the pie shell for 5 minutes prior to adding filling.  I will definately make this recipe again.  The cheddar cheese was very crisp on top and due to personal preference I will probably add it 10-15 minutes before the quiche is finished next time so that it's more stringy.

text:
This was the best quiche ever! My husband and I both loved it. After reading the other reviews I too made a few changes. I cooked the crust 5-7 minutes before adding the ingredients and so my crust turned out perfect on the bottom. I cut the butter to ¼ cup and…no grease so that worked well. I took the garlic down to 2 cloves and frankly I could have done 3 I think. The spinach I used was fresh so I just cooked it down in a little water and then drained it. Also, the feta only comes in a 4 oz package now so that’s all I used. Lastly I cut the milk to ½ cup and the eggs to 3. It turned out perfectly and it was the first time I ever made quiche. I felt like I needed something with a little texture so I served it with a side salad in a balsamic vinaigrette. Delicious! I can’t wait to experiment more with different ingredients!

This recipe was absolutely FANTASTIC!!  I made a few adjustments.  I used Havarti cheese instead of feta (I'm not a big feta fan), I switched out the milk for heavy whipping cream and I used 1/4 butter.  I also added a little sherry wine and green onions as well as red onions.  My daughter was not a big fan of quiche but she came RUNNING in my room saying "mommy, this is the BEST quiche EVER!" With that being said I highly recommend this quiche to everyone!!!!!!

text:
This is a wonderful dish!  My husband was pretty leary of it at first, but he ended up loving it, and eating almost the entire quiche by himself.  I made a few minor adjustments--I reduced the butter to 1/4 cup because 1/2 cup seemed like way too much.  I also reduced the cheese by about half, and it was plenty.  Also, put the cheese on right at the end; if you put it on as directed you will end up with a brown, crusty mess.

text:
Really delicious quiche.  I baked the crust for 6 min before adding the egg mixture.  Saute the onion and fresh mushroom in 1 tbsp of butter.  add garlic right at the end so it doesn't burn.  remove from heat and stir in spinach, plain feta, 1 tsp of dill and 6 oz cheddar cheese.  in a medium bowl, whisk eggs and milk.  add salt and pepper.  Mix spinach mixture and egg mixture and pour into crust.  Bake for 50 minutes.  let stand 10 min.

text:
This is good...BUT... 1) The amount of ingredients did not fit into one deep dish crust - this recipe makes 2 quiches, not one.  At least not with the "deep dish" crust I bought.  I did not realize it until I was pouring in the egg/milk mixture that it would not fit.  I had to grab another pie pan, move half of the spinach mixture to the second pan, and then split the egg/milk mixture between the two...2) Half a cup of butter is one stick!  WAY too much.  Thankfully I realized that immediately.  I used 2 tablespoons and even that was too much.  With all the cheese in this recipe, no wonder it still came out greasy.  I will definately do this again, but I will probably only use 1 tbsp of butter, no additional salt, and a little less cheese.  BTW, my changes are as follows: fresh spinach and mushrooms, evaporated milk, and a mexican blend of cheeses.

text:
My husband had invited a colleague to dinner recently. I know the rule about trying new recipes on guests but this looked so good, I couldn't resist. Well, this came out so well that both the men had seconds.

I will offer a word of caution to anybody like me (in rural Australia) that cannot get a large pie crust, you will only be able to fit half the filling in a small crust. I used the leftovers next day by filling muffin tins and making mini-quiches. These came out really well, too.

I will be making this again. It's very nice in the summer with a salad. Highly recommended.

text:
I got great results by 1) using just 1T butter; 2) squeezing the water out of the spinach and then adding it to the sauté for a minute to cook off extra moisture; 3) adding 1/4 cup sliced artichoke hearts instead of mushrooms; 4) using just 4oz feta and 2oz cheddar; and 5) mixing everything together (except the cheddar) before pouring it in the pie shell.

userID:
2593213
Display Name:
Robin
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
7
favoritesCount:
192
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/265795.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is fabulous, and like the recipe says, very forgiving. Feel free to play around with it to make a whatever-you-want-it-to-be quiche, but here is what I did to make it a little better. First off, 1/2 cup of butter is ridiculous; all you really need is about 1tbs. I used two small bags of organic spinach - washed and chopped - from the farmers market, 4 medium shallots, 3 cloves of garlic, goat cheese, green onions, fresh parsley and thyme, and a strong white welsh cheddar (I didn't have any mushrooms otherwise those would have gone in too). I sauteed the shallots and garlic in the butter than added the spinach. Make sure to squeeze as much water out of the spinach as possible for adding it to the pan though, as this will keep it from make the quiche too watery (same goes for frozen spinach). I added the spinach mixture to the pie crust and then sprinkled it with goat cheese. I beat the eggs with the milk and added salt and pepper and about 2 tbs fresh chopped parsley and 1tsp fresh thyme to the mixture. I made my own pie crust in a deep dish glass pie plate which I partially baked before adding the rest of the ingredients. Unlike others, I found that I actually didn't have enough filling to fill the crust so I added another egg to the mixture. I topped it with about 1 cup grated welsh cheddar (yum!) and a handful of chopped green onions, although I wish I had added more green onions now. This came out FABULOUS and is probably one of the best quiche recipes I've tried.

Unbelievably Great!  We danced around the oven huffing the yummy smells while it baked.  I only used 2 TA butter to cook the onions, and garlic.  I threw fresh mushrooms on the pile once the onions had cooked about 6 minutes.  I pre-cooked my pie shell for 7 minutes as others had recommended to keep the crust from getting too soggy.  I used plain feta (all I had on hand) and added a dash of dried rosemary, basil and oregano to the skillet.  I ended up using colby-jack in place of the suggested cheddar (again, it was all I had in the fridge), 4 eggs and 3/4 cup of half n half (same fridge related story)..used up 95 percent of the egg/half n half mixture.  I had a frozen pie shell, not deep dish.  For selfish reasons I am writing this detailed review down so I can make this exacatly again. Wow, wow, wow... this recipe is so good.

text:
I omit the butter completely and saute the veggies in a tbsp of olive oil instead. I opt for healthier substitutions: egg beaters, 2% cheddar and skim milk or fat free half & half. I've experimented with fat free feta and the herb/garlic variety. Both are delicious but the herb/garlic does add an extra level of flavor & richness. Bump up the antioxidants by adding red pepper too. I find it easier to mix everything in a bowl before filling the crust... regardless, this recipe is wonderful!

This is delicious!! I used 1/2 cup of butter just because I wanted it  to be really velvety. It was. I couldn't find a deep dish pie crust at my grocery store so I used 2 regular 9 inch pie crusts. This is the first quiche I ever made and I am very happy with the results. I only put feta IN the quiche, but I topped each quiche with a handful of cheddar 15 minutes into baking.

text:
First time I ever made a quiche, and everyone at the party loved it!!! I followed what others had recommended:

I used 1 tbsp butter to saute the onions and garlic til brown. I used fresh spinach and after put them on the same skillet once the onions and garlic were brown. they wilted down nicely. I then added the mushrooms and the feta and cheddar. For my crust, Well this recipe is enough for 2 quiche! I let my crust sit in the over for 5 minutes, when I removed it I sprinkled cheddar on the bottom, and then I added the mixture evenly into both pies. I whisked 4 eggs and half a cup of milk with salt and pepper and poured them on top, and followed the rest of the recipe.. I was so proud that it came out so well, especially since it was my first time!!

KittyBrown

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/414734.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great basic quiche recipe. Like another reviewer, I used the single crust recipe available on this site for my crust: 1 1/4 cup AP flour, 1/2 tsp salt, 1/3 cup shortening and about 5 tablespoons water.   I also pre-baked the crust for about 5 minutes before adding the rest of the ingredients in.  For my ingredients, I definitely didn't use any butter, (1/2 would have been way too much anyway) but I sauteed some onion and garlic in olive oil and then added about 3 cups fresh spinach, 5 fresh mushrooms sliced, and 1/4 cup diced red pepper. I let these ingredients saute until the spinach was fully wilted. Then I added 1/2 cup mozzarella cheese at the last minute and poured into the pastry shell followed by the egg mixture. I added the additional cheese as directed.   This is a great way to get rid of any leftover ingredients you have in your fridge at the end of the week. I will make it again!

text:
The best quiche I've ever had!!!!
This is such an easy recipe and so yummy.  I did alter it sligtly to decrease the fat and calorie content.  Replacing the butter with olive oil, whole milk with fat-free milk, the whole eggs with egg whites and the cheeses with reduced fat cheese.  I also used fresh mushrooms, cooking them with the onions and garlic.  Delicious.  My husband usually hates quiche but he thought it smelled so good while cooking that he'd give it a try and ending up eating half of it before I even had 1 piece.  My 4 year old and 1 year old gobbled it up as well.  I also took the advice of others and cooked the pie crust for a few minutes before adding the ingredients.  Next time, I think I'll try a crustless to decrease the fat and calories even more.

The original recipe must be incredible because my low-fat, low-cal version was awesome.

text:
loved this recipe. absolutely wonderful. as suggested by the other reviewers, i made a few changes. here's a general summary: 1) i baked the pie in the oven for about 2-3 minutes. any more, and the pie would have overbaked. when baking, make sure you poke a fork in the bottom a few times otherwise, the crust will bubble. 2) i only used 1/4 cup butter (1/2 stick) and that was even too much. 3) instead of just Cheddar cheese, i used to 1/2 Cheddar and 1/2 mozzerella. 4) i didn't have any preseasoned feta so i crumbled regular feta and added thyme, oregeno, basil, and garlic pepper. 4)both the spinach filling and the milk mixture turned out to be too much. i used only four eggs and a little less milk. 5) to the spinach mixture, i also added i diced red bell pepper.

Wonderful recipe! This is the best base for quiche I've found. I make this quiche all the time... I love it because it's quick and easy to add whatever ingredients you might have in your kitchen. I sometimes add pimentos, fresh mushrooms, green chlies, or artichoke hearts (my favorite!). And throw in whatever kind of cheese you might have lying around too. I usually cut the butter and the milk in half, and I skip the cheese on top part because I'm lazy. It ALWAYS turns out great. I made one last night and I accidently forgot about it in the oven for almost 20 minutes over the bake time... to my surprise it was a little brown on top, but still perfectly delicious!  Highly recommended. :)

text:
Due to where I am located in the world, I had to make a few substitutions.  Instead of frozen spinach, I used fresh, and instead of jarred mushrooms, I used fresh, chopped mushrooms that I had sauteed in butter.  I also had to add my own herbs to the (plain) feta cheese.  I didn't bother making a pie crust (no frozen ones here), so I just poured the ingredients in the dish and it came out like a casserole instead of a traditional quiche.  I served this dish at a party that was attended by a vegetarian and a low-carb dieter--perfect for both!  Everyone raved about it, so I am making it again tonight for some friends who are coming over.  It was best when fresh, but the reheated leftovers were also good.

userID:
12225252
Display Name:
Candice
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe as written except made a few personal touches. I used a 9" Pillsbury frozen unbaked pie shell. Thaw and baked 11 minutes, which is on the product wrapper. Only used 1/4 cup butter to sauté instead of 1/2 cup. Instead of canned mushrooms, I used fresh, sliced mushrooms to taste. Sautéed these along with the onion and garlic and spinach. In place of 1/2 cup shredded cheddar, I used 1/4 cup mozzarella shredded and then divided the feta half plain and half flavored. Placed completed mixture into the cooled pie shell. I only used 1/2 cup milk beaten with the eggs and slowly poured over the spinach mixture. I poured small amounts of the eggs/milk mixture into the solids a few times so the liquid would be absorbed. If you pour all the liquid in at one time, then it doesn't absorb well and the liquid runs off which is what I'm reading happened in some of the other reviews. Then, finally 1/4 cup of shredded mozzarella was put on top and pie was baked and cooled.  My husband said it was literally the best quiche he's ever had in his life!  It was moist and made excellent left-overs.   Thank you for submitting this quiche recipe!

text:
I used fresh spinach only (no mushrooms).  2 large "freezer bags" full of spinach.  It sautés down to the perfect amount for one quiche. Also added some minced country ham to give it some smoky flavor. One spice to add to the egg mixture is nutmeg. I didn't add the cheese at the end, but I used a combination of jalapeno jack cheddar and baby swiss in the mixture. Once you put the egg mixture over the spinach, take a fork and lightly fluff everything together.I will also say, use 1/2 stick butter max. Fresh spinach is the way to go. -Rally'smom

text:
I don't typically leave reviews, but after using this recipe dozens of times, I knew I owed it to the creator to take the time and say how amazing this recipe is.  I've made this spinach quiche countless different ways and every version, including the original, always turns out perfect.  The original recipe is incredible -but- some variations I've created: making my own whole wheat pie crust, baking it with no crust at all and using all low fat and fat free ingredients {i.e. low fat feta, fat free cheddar, skim milk, low fat Brummel & Brown yogurt butter, etc...}, I've even replaced the 10 ounces of spinach with 10 ounces of crab meat, have replaced the spinach with bacon and used all Swiss cheese - stunning, every way you bake it.

text:
Tweeked somewhat to what I had on hand. Used no butter. Sauteed 1/2 lb fresh mushrooms with sliced green onions and garlic. Added 1 lb of fresh spinach and black pepper. No salt needed with Feta. Let drain in a mesh colander about an hour. Beat 3 eggs with 1/2 c. milk, added the feta and mozzarella cheese. Baked the crust for seven minutes. Combined spinach mixture with egg mix and filled deep dish shell perfectly. Baked until golden topped with more mozzarella - baked until melted. Fantastic!! My husband and I really enjoyed this and it will be in our regular rotation.

city:

country:
None
text:
Great idea but yes, the proportions are off.  My suggestions, cut butter down to 2 tblsp., cut the cheese (no pun intended) by half and use 16 oz. of light sour cream instead of the milk.  This perfectly fills 1 pie shell and makes it nice and firm.  Nothing worse than a soggy or mushy quiche.  Another easy thing to do is just saute the first 5 ingredients, Then mix the rest in a large bowl.  Combine them in the end and pour in the shell.  It helps with consistancy. The feta, garlic, spinach combo is fabulous.  Red pepper is a nice touch too.

I stuck pretty close to the recipe as it is written.  I didn't have any feta on hand, so I left that out.  I also added about 5 slices of crispy chopped bacon which gave it a nice flavor.  And I reduced the milk to 1/2 a cup.  The end result was great!  It was just moist enough without being soggy.

text:
This is probably one of the best quiches I've ever had, and as a vegetarian I go through a lot of quiche! There's a trick to making this one, though - I have to cook my pie crusts beforehand so they don't come out still gooey by the time the egg/cheese is done, and I layer the spinach and egg mixtures to get a more even spread. Olives make a great addition... but so would just about anything. :)

text:
Great Quiche base recipe.  I've made this several times recently and have received rave reviews every single time. I have made quite a few changes - but I think this is a good base recipe.  You can pretty much add any type of veggie and cheese you like.  I've made it a tad healthier by using a combo of egg beaters, turkey sausage, onion, green pepper, mushrooms and reduced fat cheddar cheese and the results are outstanding.  The cooktime remains the same.  Great recipe!

text:
Finally -- a quiche recipe I would make again! I followed the recipe exactly, only omitting the mushrooms.  I used sharp cheddar which complemented the tang of the feta nicely.  I also precooked the crust for about 7 minutes so I didn't get any soggy spots in the center of the crust.  I was so pleased by this recipe because the eggs were neither runny nor overcooked - they stayed moist even after reheating for leftovers the next day.  I served with a fruit salad and french bread which was a wonderful contrast to the savory flavors.

text:
This was really simple.  I almost messed it up, though:  I am not sure if you were supposed to pre-bake the pie shell or not, but I did prebake it and because of that, the crust almost burnt when I baked it with the filling in it (I had to put foil over the edges and it still got too browned).  I had extra filling, I think it will fill a second pie crust...it's in the freezer for a lazy day.  The flavor is really good.  I didn't have herbed feta, just regular, and that was good in it.  I also used fresh mushrooms instead of canned.  I highly recommend this recipe! *** UPDATE *** I've made this recipe many times with great success.  I usually use feta without herbs but this last time I used 6 oz of herbed feta, my husband said it was the best way I made it.  Picky family member loves it and went back for seconds.

city:

country:

text:
This is a great recipe.  I modified it to make it a little lighter, and it turned out wonderful!  I only used 1 tbs of butter to sautee the garlic and onions per other reviewers' comments about the "grease factor."  In addition to the other ingredients, I used egg substitute (5 egg equivalents), 3.5 oz reduced fat feta cheese, ~6oz spinach (that's all I had left), and 8oz of reduced fat cheddar shreds.  I also excluded the milk because I didn't have time to drain the spinach.  I just mixed everything together instead of working it layer by layer, and it's delicious.  Other reviewers were right about not needing salt at all.  The cheese definitely takes care of that!

text:
This was my first attempt at quiche and it came out absolutely delicious! I read the comments before trying out the recipe, so I had an idea of what I was getting into. I omitted the mushrooms and feta cheese, used only 1 tbsp butter + 1 tbsp olive oil to sautee the veggies, used a little more than 1/2 cup of SKIM milk, and used only 2 eggs. I also added 1/4 cup parmesan cheese to the egg mixture along with a couple tbsp of fresh chopped parsley. I had just the right amount of veggies + egg mixture to fill the 9" deep dish crust. This was a quick and easy meal that I feel I can make any time. Highly recommended!

This is a wonderful quiche recipe.  I used to regular pie shells.  Sauteed fresh spinach with the onions and garlic, added fresh sliced mushrooms sauteed in butter.   I used regular feta and riccotta in a mixture to equal six ounces and sprinkled Mrs. Dash Tomato, Basil and Garlic seasonings along with seasoned salt and fresh cracked tri-colored pepper.  Baked for 50 minutes and this dish is superb!  Take it from a former breakfast chef from a local B&B.  I served it with fresh sliced Georgia Peaches and Blueberries and Pumpernickel Toast with Homeade HoneyBell Orange Marmalade.

Very savory recipe - excellent taste! I made this recipe the night before and served it as one dish the next day at a baby shower brunch. It was very popular! I used 3T olive oil instead of the 1/2 cup butter, 4 cloves of garlic instead of 3, 4oz feta instead of 6oz, 6oz cheddar instead of 8oz. I like this quiche well enough but the time to cook is off by quite a bit. The in-oven time alone is 55 minutes with 10 minutes to sit after so that's already an hour and 5 mins without counting the preparation time.  This is crucial when I come home from work and need to know at a quick glance how long dinner will take to get on the table. I hope the recipe owner will amend this. Otherwise this is a very good quiche that I use for Meatless Mondays a lot.

country:
None
text:
I like to switch this recipe up a little. I make 24 mini quiches in a muffin pan and freeze them to eat throughout the week. Two or three and a fruit smoothie make a great breakfast! I use Ruth's Grandma's pie crust recipe and just put the pie crust on the bottom of the muffin liners, cooking the crust for 5 minutes before adding the mixture, then for 25 minutes. Also, fresh spinach and mushrooms make this recipe! The fresher the ingredients the better it tastes after being frozen all week. We never have feta in my house so I use a white Italian cheese blend instead.
Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:

userID:
6974221
Display Name:
ConkyJoe
isPro:
False
followersCount:
38
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
263
favoritesCount:
7945
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/703426.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very tasty and disappeared quickly. Made some changes. Based on repeated issues in the reviews about being too oily and wet, cut butter to 1/4 cup (half stick) and milk to 2/3 cup. Egg-washed the pie crust, and baked for 7 minutes before filling to resist a soggy bottom pie crust. Used fresh mushrooms rather than canned, and added sweet peppers and fresh basil when cooking the spinach mixture. Used 4 ounce package of herb & garlic feta as it’s now commonly packaged in a smaller size. Placed thinly sliced green onions on top of pie as last step before baking. With added ingredients, it almost perfectly filled a Mrs. Smith’s 9 inch deep dish pie pan close to the top (about 1/4 cup excess egg mixture) . . . had no oven spillover as others say they encountered although pie tin placed inside an extra deep ceramic pie dish just in case. While it will be made again as made this time, we’ll also try another version with 8 ounces of herb & garlic feta but no cheese on top, even less or no butter, and 1/2 cup milk with a glug of sherry. A definite keeper!!

Used less then 1/4 c. Butter

Used 4 c. fresh spinach

text:
Awesome! I also made a modified version, no pie crust, just baked the ingredients in greased cup cake pans. I used no butter, only olive oil to saute the onions and garlic. I also added the (fresh) mushrooms and (fresh) spinach for a few minutes to cook them down to better fit in the cupcakes. I used 5 eggs and only a few splashes of milk. I added the cheeses separately per cupcake cup, just a pinch of each. The cooking time was a lot less, 10 min/ add cheddar to top/ then another 10-15min depending on the pan. Turned out great! It made 12 mini quiches!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2660908.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did as other reviewers suggested and halved the amount of onion and spinach and cheese.  I did leave more mushrooms in to make for a happy family, though :D  

The other thing I did was omit the feta cheese, instead opting to make the recipe entirely with cheddar.  We don't like feta cheese much and since it would have been too much cheese anyway...

I sauteed the veggies in just a touch of olive oil instead of butter, used skim milk and egg beaters, and 2% cheese instead of full fat, and it turned out to be a MUCH lighter version of the quiche while still being tasty!  Will definitely make this again

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I absolutely love this recipe. A stick of butter, and nearly a pound of cheese tastes so delicious. But it was really too much cheese and I only used 4 oz of feta.

I'd say cut the feta to 4 oz and cheddar to 4 or 5, still putting a half cup of the cheddar in the quiche and the rest on top. 

Be sure when you thaw the spinach to squeeze it dry afterwards. The quiche ended up soggy when I forgot to do this.

Having made this twice I'm not sure how to keep the egg mixture from spilling over the top when I add it. The extra water from the spinach may have contributed. Maybe I need a better pie pan with higher edges. And next time I'm going to have the pie pan on the baking pan on the oven rack before I add the eggs so almost no movement is needed.

text:
Left this review on one of the modified version. Should probably leave it on the original as well:

A perfect quiche. I've made quiches before where it's more of a vegetable pie with the ingredients not really meshing together. This is different. Spinach and mushrooms complement each other perfectly. And surprisingly, it's not the cheddar but the feta that really does the trick in tying together all the ingredients. You get the richness with the mushrooms and the healthy goodness with the spinach. The only thing I added was a pinch of freshly ground nutmeg. Got a week's worth of lunches out of one gigantic quiche. Keeps very well. This one's a keeper! Thanks!

Some more mods I made:
I used a couple tablespoons canola oil instead of the butter. I also used fresh spinach and fresh mushrooms, sauteed down so as most of their water is gone. Also, as others have said, this recipe does make too much for one deep dish store-bought pie shell. I just cooked the overflow in a few ramekins without the pastry. Didn't stick much because of all that yummy cheese!

userID:

Display Name:
threadartist

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good recipe.  If you want to make just one quiche, use 1/4 cup or less (next time I will use 3 T because I think 1/4 is still just a tad too much).  I used fresh spinach and wilted it after the onions and garlic was simmered.  Fresh mushrooms are better.  Only used 1 garlic clove because other family members have a sensitve tummy, havarti cheese instead of feta, and to make it very creamy and not too liquidy, use 2 full eggs and 2 egg yolks instead of all four eggs.  Also using 1 cup of heavy cream made it perfect.  To test if done, slide a butter knife about 1-1/2 inches from the outside rim.  If it comes out clean, it's ready to be taken out of the oven.  Allow it to stand for 10 minutes and then try to only eat one piece.  You won't be able to stop with just one piece.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
VERY very yummy recipe! Made it for a bunch and got all rave reviews. A few things worth mentioning: a HALF a cup of butter is unnecessary. You're sauteeing onion and garlic... don't get me wrong, butter is one of my food groups, and i don't believe I ever cut back in a recipe, but a T is perfectly fine. I also used light cream, which made the consistency extra creamy/custardy. And the spinach mix is about 2 C more then what you need for a standard 9 in pie pan. Add a bit more and you can easily have 2 quiches out of the recipe. The main substitution I did was mozzerella instead of chedder, just seemed more fitting. It's actually good with either, but I personally like mozz better in a recipe like this. I would highly suggest Martha Stewart's "Pate Brisee" recipe for the pie crust.  Excellent recipe! I will be making this again!

I use bought crusts with my own pie plate.

text:
This is the best quiche I've ever tasted! I make it into 8 servings instead of 6 but it's still gone within 2 days between my boyfriend and I!  I have to start making 2-3 at a time!  Only changes I made were using a little less butter (1 heaping tbsp), using fresh mushrooms instead of canned, using bagged baby spinach instead of frozen, and cutting the egg/milk amounts in half because there's not enough room for it all in the pie crust.    For those folks who don't like an eggy quiche or don't like quiche because it's eggy, this is the perfect recipe.  I have friends who don't like quiche but love this!

text:
Yum! I could only find feta in 4 oz. pkgs, so I use 2 of those (8 oz.) and then made 1.5 times the recipe for the rest of the ingredients (meaning 6 eggs, more mushrooms, 1.5 pkg. of spinach, etc.), but kept the same amount of milk 1 c.--although it probably would have worked with more milk. This filled 2 regular sized pie pans (used frozen pie crusts, pre-baked for 7 minutes with edges covered in foil) and a sm. creme brulee sized dish. The crust really makes  this recipe though, because the smaller one was crustless and it wasn't nearly as good. Also, I didn't wait to throw in the cheese (oops! didn't follow directions!), so I just turned down the temp. Overall, really good. I figure since this is already loaded with calories, this might taste better with half & half or a bit of sour cream instead of milk. I normally make my quiches with bacon or ham, but I was bringing this to a work function and quite a few of my co-workers were Catholic, so they don't eat meat on Fridays (Lent). I'll make this super flexible recipe again. I'd also like to add that the feta cheese was barely noticeable, flavors really meshed well. Thanks!

text:
We really enjoyed this recipe; it was fluffier than others I have made in the past.  I only used 4 tablespoons of butter and it was plenty, with all the cheese it was rich enough and you really do not need it.  I made this twice once with cheddar and feta, and one with Swiss and little cheddar(little bland), both very good, but we prefer recipe as stated.  When making my quiches, I have always brush 1 tsp Dion mustard on bottom of uncooked pie crust, for little flavor.  I mixed all the ingredients together, instead of pouring the egg mixture over the spinach mixture, and it came out great. I would definitely make this recipe again.

text:
This was my first quiche and it was delicious!  As Bailey stated, the recipe is very forgiving, allowing you to modify to suit your taste.  Like some, I used 1 fewer egg and 3/4 of cup of 1% lactaid free milk, I also substituted olive oil for the butter and 6 oz of marinated artichoke hearts for the mushrooms. Again, delicious! Finally, as with some of the other reviews, I pre-baked the crust for 5-7 minutes and would recommend adding the top layer of cheese during the last 15 minutes of the cooking process; otherwise the cheese will be too brown.

What a terrific recipe!  I followed the previous reviewers and cut the butter & salt out entirely.  I would also suggest you reverse the timing of the cheese topping.  Bake for 45 minutes, then add the cheese (I use white cheddar so it looks prettier) for the final 15 minutes of baking.  When I followed the original recipe the cheese browned way too much.

country:

text:
I made this quiche for a potluck I went to this evening.  I was worried how quiche would go over in a crowd but the recipe sounded so tasty and the number of positive reviews was impressive!  I did make a few changes... For one, I don't know how the entire spinach and egg mixtures would have fit into a single 9-inch crust.  I used TWO deep dish crusts and it fit perfectly.  Instead of using mushrooms which I personally don't care for, I used 4 chopped (canned) artichoke hearts.  I also couldn't find the garlic herb feta so I used tomato basil feta.  I also used advice from other reviewers and baked the crusts before filling them for about 10 minutes but I think that was a bit too long, perhaps 7 minutes would have been just right, 5 minutes wasn't long enough.  I was concerned about soggy bottoms!  I also added sliced tomatoes to the top after the initial 15 minute bake time.  I sprinkled the remaining cheese over the tomatoes and baked an additional 35 minutes - perfect!  And BOTH quiches were eaten by the guests at the potluck, always a nice feeling!  :)  I will be making this one again and it's nice that it really is so versatile.

This personally is one of my favorite recipes. Make this dish for nearly every potluck I go to or office luncheons. However, I do make changes per suggestions in the reviews. I use less butter than suggested, I add more garlic. Always use feta that that has flavor, never use the plain feta. And I always tend to reduce the egg amount, only because my dish ends up overflowing. All in all, wonderful dish!

text:
This is great because it's so easy to make and so easy to alter to exactly what you want. Plus, you can make it fairly healthy by using egg beaters, fat free half and half, and definitely only need a 1/4 c or less of butter to brown the garlic. Also, I used fresh spinach, fresh mushrooms, and added red peppers, orange peppers, and green onion. If you add just a little extra milk/half and half and egg, you can definitely get 2 pies out of this recipe. Yummy.

We were having our vegetarian friends over for dinner and this was my first time making quiche so I was a bit nervous but it was wonderful!  Everyone loved it and even went for seconds. I did bake the crust for about 10 minutes before adding the mixture to it and it was not soggy when we cut into it.  I used skim milk and only used about 1 tbls of butter which worked out well.  I would definitely make it again.

text:
Can you say LOVE?  This recipe was fantastic...but oh so rich!  I cut out so many things and it was still so filling and I don't think I missed anything on the flavor side with my substitutes.  I used a small amount of olive oil to sautee the garlic & onions versus the butter.  I also used 1/2 cup fat-free sour cream & 1/2 cup skim milk with the eggs.  I used the full 6 oz of feta (it's one of my favs), but only used 1 cup of 2% cheddar which I just put on top.  Ohhh...and I went crust free...DELISH!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Add Me to the list! I followed some others advice and made 2 pies. I used 1 cup of milk and 6 large eggs and used fresh mushrooms.I messed up and started to put the whole 8 oz pkg of cheddar in and caught myself at about 1/2 the bag  instead of the 1/2 cup. It didn't hurt much thankfully, except I think the pies would have been a touch moister. Since I didn't have the correct remaining amount of cheese to sprinkle on top, I added enough shredded swiss to make up the difference. I liked that and will do that again, probably 1/2 of each. I preheated the oven to 375, baked the shells for 5 minutes before filling them.  I turned the temp down to 325 when I put the filled pies in, baked for 20 minutes, removed and added the cheese and covered the edges with foil, baked for about 10 minutes more til set.  FYI: I also sprinkled a touch of nutmeg in the mixture and also on top after it was baked. I served it with fresh fruit salad. My 7 year old DGD and I liked it served with a dollop of sour cream, DH liked it with hot sauce. And I didn't think the Feta was overpowering at all as some others thought,  But I like Feta!

text:
This was super-easy to make and even easier to eat! I added artichoke hearts and substituted fresh mushrooms for canned. I also sautéed the mushrooms, onions and artichoke hearts. I only used 3 eggs and a bit less milk than was called for and it was quite yummy. Next time, I will be certain to add jalapenos to give it a bit of a kick, as it was a little calm (notice I did NOT say bland). The men topped it off with hot sauce, but I've never been a fan of salsa with eggs. Still, quite a delicious dish. Mine wasn't mushy or wet at all. A great basic recipe to tinker with.

This is my first quiche & it was ok. I  probably have to make a little adjustments though. This dish was extremely salty because of the feta. Next time I think NO salt is a must. I cooked it with NO butter....Just a little Extra Virgin Olive Oil was fine. I didn't add any salt to the filling but I did add a pinch in the eggs which I shouldn't have because the dish was a little too salty for me. Also, I used a lot less milk than the recipe suggested, with only 3 eggs.

I have made this recipe several times with a few variations and each time it has been excellant. I don't use the half cup of butter. I simply saute the onions in a little bit of oil or maybe some margarine. I also use plain feta. I always get at least two quiches out of this recipe and by adding another 2 eggs and half cup of milk, I can get 2 deep dish quiches. This will continue to be in heavy rotation in my kitchen. Try adding bacon or portabella mushrooms too.

This took a while to cook, in part because i kept checking it, cutting a small section in the middle and getting a lot of water come up.  I recommedn that you REALLY let the spinach dry out.  I thought I had squeezed a lot of the water out, but I think it could have used more.  AS long as the top is firm and crusty (with the cheese) your quiche will be done and will REALLY be enjoyed by everyone!
(I used a ready-made pie crust found in the diary section of the grocer's.

This is an excellent recipe.  I too agree that the butter is just way to much.  I would suggest just 3 tablespoons. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First quiche I've made as I'm testing recipes out to feed a small crowd for breakfast. 

I read most reviews and did buy the 9" Deep Dish Pie and just used 2-3 TB of butter. I used 5 eggs and 1 cup milk but had a tad extra so I'd either do 4 eggs or just less milk next time. I used fresh mushrooms and fresh spinach and saute'd them with the garlic and onion in the beginning.  After saute'ing I added to the whisked egg/milk bowl, and then added the feta (regular). Stirred up a bit and added salt/pepper and poured into my pie crust.

I did bake the crust for 6 minutes before pouring my mix in. Baked 15 min then added cheddar and baked final 35 minutes. I didn't cover edges with foil and it came out perfect. Tastes good too! Will keep this recipe! Others have said you can prepare it night before and bake in the morning. I may do that!

text:
don't you hate it when people change the recipe & then rate it? Well...I was just checking this recipe for proportions before making my spinach quiche. I had a freezer thaw and needed to use up some creamed spinach. I love using it in a quiche...the seasonings & cream sauce work & you don't need much butter or prep. I used one box of creamed spinach, cut the butter back to 2 tablespoons. I prefer swiss cheese & parmesan over cheddar with delicate spinach nutmeg is a must as well a pinch of ground Cheyenne pepper. Add chopped artichokes for variation with thinly sliced tomatoes on the top before baking for color and flavor. Good basic recipe...without all the butter!

text:
This is a great base Quiche recipe.  I cut the butter by half, used  unsweetened almond milk (we are lactose intolerant), omitted the muchrooms, feta added 2oz of turkey; Did not saute garlic and onions. I pre baked the pie shell for 10 minutes and then poured in the mixture to the shell and topped with slices of tomato, more cheddar and a sprinkle of nutmeg. 
My husband said it was one of the best Quiche I've ever made, my boys ate it and asked for 2nds. They NEVER DO! Will continue to use as my new base.

text:
I made a few changes and one major mistake, so it might be my fault that this recipes was delicious but not mind-blowing.  It was almost mind-blowing.  It was . . . mind breezing.  I left out the onion because I'm really not into onion and I left out the garlic and herb feta, because it just sounded kind of gross.  I'm also kind of ishy on spinach, so I pre-cooked the spinach it by sauteing it in a little bit of butter, as per my mother's suggestions.  This was a mistake.  The spinach became way too wet, and I couldn't get the quiche to cook firm.  In spite of that, it tasted very good.  My other issue with this recipe is that there's no way you can fit all of this in one pie crust.  Do like another review recommended: double the recipe and make three pies.  You'll end up eating them all.

text:
So good. This was the first quiche I ever made. It costs between 8 and 10 dollars to make because the feta was $5 and the cheddar was $2. It is VERY rich. But it was so good, that my boyfriend and I couldn't stop eating it. We ate the whole thing, no sides. Because it has so many calories, after this I didn't eat anything else that day. In the future, I will make a salad with it and make sure we ration it out over a few days so as to have a more balanced diet. Sorry to bring attention to it, but this dish is mostly fat. There are lower calorie quiche recipes on this site. Something with less butter and less cheese would be better.

city:

country:
None
text:
Hi. This turned out fabulous for me. I did make a few adjustments. I made my own crust. I used fresh spinach and cooked it down, fried my onions with it and added 4 medium cloves of garlic at the very end,  so it didn't burn. 
I didn't use mushrooms. I did add a teaspoon of Greek seasoning.
I didn't add any extra butter. Just the olive oil I used to cook the spinach.
I used fat free feta. 
And 2% milk. 
I followed the rest of the directions. 
If you use a 9' deep dish pie pan it will fit perfectly. 
There is even room for extra ingredients if you wish. 
I baked for a total time of 50 mins @ 375° 
Absolutely perfect.

text:
It's always a happy thing when I find a recipe that the whole family likes, including my vegetarian daughter!  This one is a keeper.  The only adjustments I make is using half the feta, the whole quantity makes it a bit too salty.  Also, when using a frozen deep dish pie shell, there is too much liquid.  I use three eggs and 1/4 c milk.  Be sure to get all the water out of the spinach--I use a strainer and press out the water with a potato masher.  Great recipe!  Thanks for sharing!

I love quiche because it's so versatile. And the ingredients in this recipe work together so well. However I gave it 4 stars because they call for way too much of the milk/eggs mixture. If you use the whole thing you end up with the mixture dripping all over your stove. I use HALF the mixture (2 eggs & 1/2 cup of milk) to make my quiche and it comes out great!

text:
Very rich and tasty.  Probably because of the butter which many reviewers have suggested could be cut way down. I sauté fresh mushrooms and fresh spinach with the onions and garlic and add a few bacon bits.
Recipe makes more filling than what will fit in a single pie crust and it is very important not to let the filling overflow.   I usually cut the butter and milk in half and I use a separate baking dish to make a crustless quiche out of the extra filling and egg mixture.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This sounded great becasue my son-in-law is a vegetarian and this recipe had no meat.  I did have to make some substitutions so I apologize that this review isn't for the recipe as shown.  1.  My family doesn't like mushrooms so substituted a drained-and-dried can of artichoke hearts.  2.  My grocery store didn't have the herb and garlic feta so I used sun-dried tomato and basil feta.  3. I personally am not fond of Cheddar cheese so I substituted a 3-cheese "pizza" mixture.  4.  I cut the butter down to 2 T.   5.  I added about 1/3-1/2 c. of toasted pine nuts.  BUT - after all that! - this was AMAZING!!  I used a 10" deep-dish pan, and it was just right for this recipe.  I waited until the last 10 minutes to sprinkle the rest of the cheese on.  I made my own crust using lard -- I know that's not a healthy thing to use, but there's just nothing like it for making pie crusts!  Anyway, the crust held up perfectly after being cut and the filling didn't fall apart at all.  And it didn't look ANYTHING like the picture on this page - much prettier!  And soooo yummy.  I'm going to make it for our church's Easter potluck on Sunday!

text:
Very simple.  Easily a five star meal if you jazz it up. I used abt 1 Tbsp evo instead of butter.  I added some herbs to the veg like oregano and thyme, then a dash of nutmeg and garlic salt to the egg.  Remember that you can cram the pie shell pretty full of toppings because the egg will fill into the crannies, and also that quiche doesn't rise so you can fil the crust to the top.  This yields a chunky, satisfying meal.  I always make twomwith different toppings (try bacon, onion, cheddar).  I am vegetarian and the veggie bacon by morningstar works great in here.

text:
WOW!!  This recipe was outstanding!!  Not the healthiest choice but really tasty!  Both my husband and I gave this one 5 stars!  I made this for a family with a new baby and modified the recipe (removed the garlic and feta) as the family has allergy restrictions.  Made a second quiche for my family and elected to leave out the feta.  After having cooked two on the same day I would tweak a few things next time.  On one quiche, I followed the recipe suggestions for butter and cheese.  That one turned out a bit greasy looking.  For the second quiche, I used less butter (just enough to cook the onions and mushrooms).  I also used about 5 oz. of cheese.  I did mix some in my mixture and only added enough on top to cover everything.  That one looked much better, had less fat and tasted amazing!  A must try meal!

text:
This is one of the best things I've ever eaten! I have made it at least 5 times so far and have a few comments. I couldn't find any herb and garlic feta at the store, so I used plain and instead substituted marinated artichoke hearts for mushrooms. The flavor balances out perfectly. Also, I have made it with the 8 tbs of butter, 4 tbs, and 2 tbs, and I have to say it is most delicious at 4 tbs. As far as the egg and milk portion of the recipe goes, it is a little too much. I use 3 eggs and 3/4 cup of milk for this, and it fits perfectly.

text:
A fabulous & tasty recipe!!
My variation: I used fresh spinach (1 lg bundle) and mushrooms (about 8 medium, sliced and chopped). I added these after the onions & garlic were lightly browned to wilt. Because the fresh veggies add moisture, you must drain about 1/3 of the liquid. Then add the seasoned feta & cheddar. Then follow the recipe from there
I also added some chopped, smoked ham (about ½ cup) when all was blended. The prep for this took a bit longer but was well worth it!! 
This was an exciting change from the “norm” and my family loved it!!

I have been making this quiche for several years now and it is fabulous!  I use fresh mushrooms and spinach.  For the fresh spinach, I just kind of eye ball the 10 oz from the number of oz in my package (it cooks way down if you've never used fresh spinach before).  I always end up with extras as well, so I just put it into a separate smaller baking dish.  Even without the crust, it is excellent!

This is a great basic recipe with a few renditions. I def cut down the butter...if that was really what you needed I just could not make this dish no matter how delicious it is lol. I used fresh spinach and fresh mushrooms and the onion. Also kept the feta which gave it such an exquisite flavor but skipped the cheddar cheese all together. I was able to make two quiches with all of that so I doubled the eggs and kept the milk the same amount. Turned out FABULOUS.  Can't wait to make it again!

text:
I used Paula Deen's Pie Crust recipe and dry baked it before putting in the filling so the crust was crispy instead of soggy.  I did not use any butter (don't need it); no mushrooms (don't like them); no feta (didn't have it); use half and half or heavy cream instead of milk for a more custardy quiche and the secret to a great custard is to add a small amout of nutmeg :)

country:
None
text:
This was my first attempt at making quiche-- it turned out perfect with some minor adjustments... I used some of the other reviews to modify the original recipe: I used the recommended amounts of spinach, cheese (along with the feta and cheddar, I added a pepper jack to the mix) and mushrooms (fresh) but divided them into two even portions. 8 eggs and only 1/2 cup of milk (1/4 for each) was used for each quiche. This recipe is so easy and you can play with different ingredients. Next time I will use fresh spinach instead of the frozen and will add meat. Oh, and you really don't need 1/2 cup butter. I'd cut that by at least half for each quiche.

country:
None
text:
I made some changes - basically a new recipie, but the spinach feta combo here is genius. Decreased butter to 3/4 stick, used fat free feta, which had no herbs so I used one extra garlic clove, oregano and thyme. added no salt as chese had enough. used 4 eggs plus 2 yolks, reduced milk to 3/4 cup and added 1 TB of sour cream. I used low fat muenster & mozarella instead of the cheddar. it made extra filling, so cut out circles of puff pastry and made little pie crusts by pushing the puff pastry circles into the muffin pan and I filled with the mix. even better than the pie dough with puff pastry.

text:
This recipe was wonderful!  I made this quiche for a friend who was visiting and is vegetarian.  Much to my surprise and delight, the rest of my family raved about it as well!  I ended up sharing the recipe with my friend and am looking forward to making it again.  I almost always make recipes exactly as they are written when trying them for the first time.  However, I agree with others here that there is too much butter.  I ended up scooping half of it out of my saute pan before continuing onwards.  Next time I'll start with just 1T and add more as seems necessary.  I also substituted regular feta for the garlic and herb variety (my store doesn't carry it).

country:
None
text:
This was really good! Of course I made a few changes b/c of what others wrote. I bought fresh spinach and chopped it up and put it in the microwave for 30 seconds which was more than enough. Then I sauteed fresh mushrooms with the garlic and the onions. Instead of the Feta cheese I used Mexican mozzarella actually made from Mexico (My relatives had just come from Mexico and they like bringing us cheese. It tastes different than the mozzarella you find in the store. I feel it taste much better). Oh I forgot to mention that I skipped on the butter and used olive oil. I also skipped the salt since the Mexican mozzarella is salty enough. In the egg and milk mix I only used two eggs and put what I thought would fit in the pie of milk. Also did not need the indicated time of cooking. Took it out when I saw it was set. My family loved it!! Even my father who doesnt really like food that isnt Mexican loved it! Thanks for sharing!

text:
I love to cook healthy....so like other have done.....I used olive oil instead of butter about 2 tbls.  added broccoli ,used 3 egg whites  and 1 whole egg and used 3/4 cup skim milk and I also cooked the pie crust a few minutes before. My secret is I lined the bottom of the crust with thin from the deli sliced swiss cheese! The crust stays flakey not soggy!  Then I added part-skim mozzerella and low fat cheddar to the mixture. I got so many compliments at dinner!!! NO one even thought it was a healthy version!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My friend sent me the link to this recipe and it is seriously one of the best things I have ever eaten.  I am on Weight Watchers, so I changed a bunch to make it much healthier (no butter, just used cooking spray/halved the feta/used fat free milk/used 2 eggs and 2 egg whites/used only 1 cup of reduced fat cheddar, mixed in, and none on top).  I also used fresh mushrooms and sauteed/deglazed the onion and garlic pan with the liquids they released.  I will split up the filling next time into two crusts.  I made it again tonight and didn't have any pie crust, but I DID have some leftover roasted red potatoes from last night's dinner, so I mixed the potatoes in with the filling and poured the egg mixture over all of it.  Wonderful recipe and SO SO easy to customize.  Thanks!

None
text:
This is a great quiche recipe - a base which I'll use in the future for other variations.  Next time I will be sure to bake the pie crust for 5-7 minutes as recommended by other reviewers because I did find the sogginess to be a disappointment.  I used a refrigerated Pillsbury pie crust and a pie dish that I don't consider to be particularly "deep dish" - however, I found that I did not have "too much" of the mixture as other reviewers have reported.  I did only use 1/2 cup of the milk - maybe that made the difference.  I also used swiss cheese instead of the cheddar - next time I will use the cheddar - I think, particularly a sharper version, would have packed a nice punch.  Omitted the mushrooms because don't love them and used a 10 oz. bag of fresh spinach in place of frozen.  I cooked down the spinach in 1 Tbsp. of olive oil.  I recommend tearing fresh spinach into smaller pieces for anyone going that route....I also used olive oil in place of butter to saute the garlic and onion - again, only 1 Tbsp.  Next time I will use butter for this step in place of the olive oil (but probably only up to 2 Tbsps) - I imagine it adds a nice richness.  I covered the edges of the pie crust with foil before baking to avoid over-browning.  Thanks!

userID:
1643883
Display Name:
stumbleine
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe, for sure.  4 eggs and 1 c. milk is a little too watery for my taste, and makes too much egg mixture for one quiche, but not enough for two.  The best thing to do (as previously mentioned) is to stick with the same amount of onion/garlic/spinach/cheeses, but when it comes to the egg mixture, use six (large) eggs, and 1 c. cream.  Divide half the spinach mixture between two pie crusts, and pour the egg mixture over that.  Make sure you blend the egg and spinach mix a little bit, I recommend using a fork to "fluff up" the spinach mixture, as it is very solid, and allow the egg mixture to infiltrate the bottom layer of spinach.  Don't worry too much about blending, though.  The quiche tastes great even if the spinach layer is a little thick on the bottom.  As for pre-baking the pie crusts before adding the ingredients, I did that the first time I made this quiche.  The crust was overly browned by the time the quiche had finished baking.  I prefer to just let the pie crusts thaw to room temp, and add the ingredients, then bake as directed.  Would've given this recipe 5 stars, but it did need a few alterations.

text:
Really easy recipe. I'll definitely make it again. I used 5 eggs and 1/2c milk as another reviewer suggested and it came out great. Next time, I'll bake my frozen pre-made pie shells a little ahead of time as the bottom came out a bit mushy. Also, when I stir fried the mushrooms, onions, garlic and cheese together, there was a bit of juice at the bottom. Next time I'll also drain it a bit, so there's less liquid in the pie before I bake. I too also had more than enough for one pie, so I made two! I tried cooking one for 40min before putting in the cheese and then the other I put the cheese in just after 15min of cooking, and both came out exactly the same!

Ah! This was so amazing- even though I doctored the recipe a little. I omitted the mushrooms, substituted parmesan for the feta, used 4 ounces of the cheddar and another 4 ounces of swiss cheese, and also crumbled bacon on the layer just above the spinach. I know it sounds like I changed a lot, but it wasn't really that much :P But it tasted absolutely FANTASTIC. I will most definitely be making it again soon- though maybe next time I'll stick to either just cheddar, or swiss, not both. It might be easier that way.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/62108.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely mouthwatering! I used 2 cloves of garlic, 3/4 cup milk, 2 tbs butter (a must for that fantastic aroma!), 3 eggs and only 1 cup of cheddar instead and DO WITHOUT the salt. The herbed feta is what made this pie so never leave it out! In the egg mixture, I added a tbs of dried parsley, a heaped tsp of oregano as well as garlic powder. Just combined the spinach mixture together with egg mixture and pour into an 11" pan. On the top, i spreaded buttered cauliflower mash, baked for 15 mins then topped with 3/4 cup of cheddar and baked for a further 30 mins. Resulted in a 'healthier top crust' and wonderful meal!

text:
First time I made quiche and it came out FANTASTIC! Per other reviewers, I made some changes - recipe in general is way too much for a 9-inch deep-dish store-bought crust so I will make two quiches next time. I used 2/3 cups half and half, 4 oz of feta (they don't sell 6 oz where I am so I opted for less), small Vidalia onion, and reduced the butter to 1 heaping tablespoon. I also put the top layer of cheddar cheese during the last 15 minutes of cook time. Mmmmmm...this was so decadent.

text:
This was a good quiche.  I followed the directions exactly, so that's what my rating is based upon.  Next time, I would make some changes: Increase to six eggs and 1 1/3 c milk, and split between two 9 inch pie crusts; use only 3/4 of the package of spinach; add some sauteed red bell pepper to the veggie mix; spread the spinach/feta mixture across the bottom of the two pans and then top with the eggs WITHOUT combining.  I thought given all the filling, it was hard to actually taste the eggs; layering will give it more of a quiche feeling.  Also, I found that there wasn't enough room for the egg mixture (I mixed eggs and spinach together before pouring in deep dish pie shell and still had to throw some away). I love the spinach and feta mixture though!  Sooo good.

Well I don't think this recipe needs anymore reviews...we all can't be wrong!
I've made this recipe at least 5 times now and changed it a bit by adding some cubbed ham or crumbled bacon, but it really needs nothing. I just wanted to add some of our favorites. Sometimes I make two and freeze one after cooking. Excellent!

I made this quiche tonight with Dana's "Butter Flaky Pie Crust"  and it was to die for! We both loved it! I added extra cheese, you can never go wrong with cheese! I also used heavy cream instead of milk. I didn't use butter, instead I used a bit of olive oil to saute. I added mushrooms and bacon pieces. And I added sun dried tomatoes to the top and covered it with cheese. The sun dried tomatoes added a bit of extra flavor. It was delicious!! I did NOT add any salt because the cheeses and sun dried tomatoes had enough salt in it. It was perfect along with a salad. :-) I'll definitly be making this again! I think next time I'll be adding ham or more chunks of meat for my carnivorous husband. :-P

We loved this. I cooked the onion in olive oil instead of butter. I subsituted a bit of ham for the mushrooms and used 3/4 C milk instead of 1 C. My husband bought 2 9in pie crusts instead of a deep dish (don't ask) so I had to make 2 & cooked them for the same ammount of time. I also baked the crusts for 5 mins in the oven before adding the other ingrediants. Thanks. We'll be making this again.

text:
I probably can't fairly rate this recipe since I made a few changes, but my quiche turned out great. I substituted chopped broccoli for the spinach because that was all that I had in the house. I think that the broccoli ends up taking up more room in the pie crust so I wasn't able to use all of the egg mixture. Despite that, it turned out great. I love the flavor addition of the feta, and I left out the salt completely because feta is naturally so salty. My husband who doesn't like quiche even ate a few slices of this quiche (maybe because it wasn't as "eggy" as other quiches). I can't wait to try the recipe with spinach next time!

text:
I needed to make this a little healthier so my changes were instead of 4 eggs I used 1 egg and 3/4 cup eggbeaters, reduced fat feta (and added a little bit of italian seasoning and garlic powder), about 4 ounces 2% shredded cheddar cheese and 1 % milk.  It was so good!  My 9 year old asked for thirds!  Make sure you do let it set for about 15-20 minutes before serving.  I will make this for guests.

country:

text:
I don't seem to be as big a fan of this recipe as everyone else, although my husband gave it a big thumb's up.  This was my first time making a quiche and I thought it was very easy to make.  For some reason, however, the spinach layer and the egg mixture never really mixed together and there were two layers.  Anyone else with this problem?  I think next time, I would just combine the two parts and then pour them into the crust.  I found the feta cheese a little overwhelming, I would cut back a little.  Also, you absolutely do not need to add any salt to this recipe, there is so much from the cheeses already.  I will try again.  (I took other reviewers' suggestions and cut way back on the butter, using 1 Tbsp. butter and 1 Tbsp. olive oil, and I cut the milk back to a 1/2 cup.  I used 4 eggs and it was just the right size for a deep dish crust.)  I had no mushrooms, fresh or canned.

text:
This is a wonderful quiche! I was looking for a recipe with spinach & mushrooms.  I didn't have any feta, so I used some blue cheese instead.  I also used some dried minced onion and sauteed it with the garlic and mushrooms.  I used butter flavored cooking spray instead of butter. I also substituted whipping cream for 1/2 of the milk.  It all fit perfectly into a deep dish crust which I had prebaked for a few minutes.  I will most definitely make this again!!

text:
YUMM.  I made my first quiche last night and used this recipe.  

I changed it up a bit...used fresh baby spinach instead of frozen, used 1/2 fake carton eggs and 1/2 real eggs, shallots instead of onion, no mushrooms, plain feta (added my own seasonings) and a little less cheese than called for!

The quiche was delicious...everyone loved it!

Next time I will leave out the salt.  The salt from the cheese is more than enough for the quiche...I thought it turned out a little too salty and I only added a pinch.

This was a wonderful quiche recipe! After reading the other reviews, I used a deep dish pie pan and was able to just have one. I poured off about half the butter after I cooked the onions and garlic (next time I will start with 1/4 cup instead) and I did mix the egg mixture with the spinach mixture before adding it to the pie shell. It all went in beautifully together! Like many other husbands, mine is not a quiche person, but he said he was looking forward to having it again!! Thanks for the recipe!!

text:
This quiche is really easy to make, although a little time consuming.  I really liked that it make more than one quiche, so I could freeze the extra one for later use.  I made this recipe for my co-workers, and I received nothing but compliments.  One suggestion I have is to use more eggs, as I found only 4 eggs does not fill up two pie crusts.  I would suggest 6 or 7 eggs total.  Otherwise, I also like this recipe since it is easy to add or subtract ingredients as well.  I added 1/2 lb cooked bacon to the recipe and it made for a nice addition.  Perhaps the best part... the finished product looks impressive, but it's very easy!

country:
None
text:
I have made this quiche twice now. I really love it. I do suggest the following modifications:

1. Less butter. No need for that much butter. Unless you want to gain 20 lbs and a heart attack. I used 1 tablespoon of smart balance butter and 1 tablespoon of olive oil. 

2. I only used 3/4 of the bag of spinach. It is a bit much. 

3. I used mozz and swiss cheese instead of cheddar to lower fat content. 

This will fit in a true deep dish pie pan. It will not fit in a "normal" sized pie pan.

text:
First time trying quiche and I was afraid of it having too much of an eggy taste/texture. BUT this was wonderful!! I cut the butter down to 3 tbs and added rosemary, basil, and oregano spices to the mixture (I was afraid the feta cheese wouldn't give enough flavour). OMG, this is absolutely delicious! I added bacon and omitted the salt. The cheese and bacon was salty enough. I have made this twice in a week. My husband ate one to himself. I'm hesitant to try other recipes now since this recipe set the bar quite high!

text:
I thought this recipe was very tasty but:
The 1/2 cup of butter mixed with the cheese made it very greasy.  Next time I will reduce the butter to 1/4 cup. I slowly added the egg mixture to the spinach mixture ( off heat) in order to guarantee that it would be nicely combined. Just cool down you spinach mixture on a plate first to keep from cooking your eggs on the egg mixture. I used plain feta as I couldn't find herbed feta.

text:
Terrific quiche recipe! My husband said it's the best he's ever had. I followed the recommendations of other reviewers and used less butter -- 2 T. --  and less milk -- 1/2 c. -- and plain feta cheese. I added about 1/4 t. dried basil. I also used a Pillsbury ready-to-bake pie crust, baking it first for 8 minutes to keep it from getting soggy on the bottom. I also sautéed fresh mushroom with the onion and garlic, rather than using canned mushrooms. Be sure to use a deep-dish pie plate, too. SO good! This will become part of our regular meal rotation.

text:
I made the filling according to the directions, except that I used less butter (~3tbs) as others suggested, and  I only used 4 oz of feta and about a  tbsp Italian seasoning.  I split the filling between two pie crusts (pre-made from Aldi) and then I added the egg/milk mixture to each of the pies.  I used 4 eggs and ¾ C of milk for each of the pies.  I baked for 15 min, added cheese as recipe suggested, then baked for another 30.  They were wonderful.  Will be making again.

text:
Great quiche base!!! Probably one of the best quiche I've ever had. I did follow other's advise and cut the grease. I used non of the butter listed. I fried bacon and used a TB spoon of the grease to sautéed onion, mushrooms, and fresh spinach (tossed in towards the end) and I threw in some leftover rotisserie chicken, and of course the bacon. Mixed everything together used 1/2 cup of cheese instead of a full cup. Pre- cooked the pie crust 10 minutes then poured in the mixture, covered the crust edges and baked 30 min. Sprinkled with cheese 1/4 cup and removed foil bake another 15 min. Perfect!

text:
Way too much fat in this recipe and it's not needed. I reduced the butter to 3 tablespoons to saute the onion/garlic and reduced the garlic to one clove. I used 3 eggs and added 1 tablespoon of flour to make sure the quiche firmed up. Added 1/8 teaspoon nutmeg for flavour and some chopped ham. I also used fresh spinach which I sauteed along with the onion and garlic to wilt it. I used Swiss cheese; cheddar is too bland for my family. I will use Gruyere cheese in future as it has even more flavor. I used 4 oz feta since I'm not crazy about feta. A good recipe with a lot of tweaks.

text:
Filling was absolutely delicious! My husband ate half the quiche the first night :) I made my own pie crust and par baked it for 10 minutes then let cool for 15 before adding the filling and eggs. I used a 9.5 inch glass pie dish and found I had  about 1/2 cup too much liquid for the dish to hold so a mix of butter and eggs spilled over the sides.  I let it set in the refrigerator for about 3 hours, then baked as recipe suggested- it came out perfectly set with a delicious crust of cheddar. Will definitely make again.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very delicious and easy to make.  I used what I had on hand for the filling:  ground beef, spinach, sautéed salami, red onion, garlic, parmesan cheese.  Important to drain the spinach well and sautee everything together and make sure the mixture is very dry.  I only used a smidgen of butter, about a 1/2 inch slice from the stick, not nearly as much as the recipe called for.  I beat the eggs and milk until frothy so it would not be dense.  The quiche turned out wonderfully light, perfectly seasoned and not greasy at all since I used very little butter.  If you want a quiche that is light, but still substantial, I say go for the meat.  Even my picky 5 yr old liked it and he won't touch anything green.  Winner!!

helpfulCount:

userID:
1709101
Display Name:
Marcia
isPro:
False
followersCount:
14

540
