photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7780135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good with several modifications.  Replaced the 4T of butter with 1T of olive oil (other reviewers reduced or eliminated the butter too), used 6 oz fresh spinach (removed the stems and chopped), 4 large fresh mushrooms, chopped, 1/3 cup of chopped sweet Vidalia onion, reduced the garlic to 1 clove, and used plain feta instead of the herbed feta.  I added 1/4 cup finely chopped green bell pepper to the mix, seasoned with pepper, but no salt (feta is quite salty), and replaced the cheddar that is sprinkled on top with grated asiago cheese.  I made a 9" pie in a gluten-free crust, but based on other reviewer's advice that there was too much filling for 1 pie, I made 4 small crust-less quiches in paper baking cups too.  The 9" pie was good, but it turned out that my deep-dish crust was plenty big enough to hold all of the filling, and it would have been better that way.  However, I'm glad I made that mistake because the little crust-less quiches were wonderful, and they only took 10 minutes to bake!  No need for a crust with this recipe, which is great for those on a gluten-free diet.  If I make this for people who can eat gluten and want a crust, I think it would be better in a crust made from a tube of refrigerated crescent rolls.

city:

country:
None
text:
It was wonderful. I made this today, Mother's Day, for brunch. I made a few changes and additions simply by preference. I used a Pyrex baking dish, sprayed, and lined the bottom only with crescent roll dough rather than using a pie crust. I also added 1/2 lb. bacon fried well but less than crisp. I also used 1/2 cup heavy cream and 1/2 cup milk rather than just milk. The recipe states baking 15 min. before topping with cheese and then finish baking. I waited 20 min. before topping with cheese. It came out golden brown enough to make me wonder if I hadn't burned the top. Amazingly, it wasn't even crisp. Topping with cheese even later in the baking time should lighten the top and hopefully the cheese will remain creamier. The egg mixture was so light and airy. I will make this many times again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was fabulous!  I did switch it up by using fresh mushrooms.  I discovered my husband had used the last of the minced garlic so I substituted it with garlic powder.  I used tomato and basil feta cheese.  Instead of using cheddar cheese, I used half sharp cheddar cheese and half Colby cheese and Monterey Jack.  We initially tried pouring the egg/milk mixture over the quiche mixture in the pie pans but the egg/milk mix went everywhere!  Once that occurred, we emptied the contents of the pie shells into a large mixing bowl.  We added the rest of the egg/milk mixture and mixed it thoroughly.  Then we returned the mixture back to the pie shells. We did have some leftover mixture.  Due to the size of our family, I made two quiches and placed them on a foil lined cookie sheet with a lip. Even for two pies, it cooked in the same amount of time as just one quiche (I do not have a convection oven).  I served fresh raspberries as a garnish.  I also prepared the easy arugula salad recipe on Allrecipes.com as a side.  This was so tasty and not hard at all.

text:
I have made this recipe a few time now.  The first time I cooked the recipe as is, which was fine except that I didn't like the crust very much.  Later I took a note from a different recipe and layered the bottom of the crust with swiss cheese.  This made all the difference in the world.  I now make a lower cal version by reducing the butter and the amount of cheese (the swiss on the bottom makes up for this).  I also use a combination of reduced and full fat cheeses.

text:
My husband and I loved this quiche! We have been married for years but this is the first quiche I have made for him because I thought he didn't like quiche.  For a sure hit, I wanted to make a more healthful quiche than Quiche Lorraine, and this was a home run!  I make my own pie crusts and for this one, in keeping with the healthful theme, I used unbleached white whole wheat flour and it was a fantastic combination. The recipe measurements were perfect and I won't change a thing the next time I make it. I don't have a deep dish stone so I used my 10" Pampered Chef pie stone (never a soggy pie crust) and it worked perfectly.  We cannot wait to have more of this quiche.  Thank you.

text:
As usual I love this recipe as a great base recipe for a delicious spinach quiche. The first time I followed the directions and it came out a bit oily (too much butter) and I had approximately half of the egg mixture left over. It was delish nonetheless!! So now my second time making it, as my boyfriend LOVED it so much last time, I've made a few changes. I used fresh mushrooms, add in marinated artichokes and used 3 eggs and 1/2 cup of milk. I still had a little of the egg mixture left over, so the next time I make it I'll try using 2 eggs and 1/4-1/2 cup of milk.

text:
Loved the recipe, EXCEPT the idea of the 1/2 C of butter.  Instead, I used about 1 1/2 T of olive oil....it was plenty to sauté the veggies, and the quiche was not oily at all.  I also used fresh mushrooms instead of canned, and I sauted them along with the garlic and onion.  I also pre-baked my pie crust for 7 minutes to make sure it got nice and crisp.  Minor changes, but they make a big difference in the outcome.  Because my husband isn't crazy about Feta, I cut that in half.  This is delicious....I just finished a piece for lunch, and I wish I had some more!!

text:
Quiche is not one of my favourite types of dish but I really enjoyed this one. I read some other reviews and took the advice of splitting the filling amount between two pie crusts instead of one. I really can't see how all of it could fit in one! 
I would also use 3/4 cup of milk next time. There was a little too much liquid. Definitely put the pies on a baking sheet unless you want this all over the bottom of your oven. I used fresh mushrooms. I couldn't find garlic and herb feta so I used regular feta and just added some italian seasoning and granulated garlic. I also doubled the amount of fresh garlic because I love having stinky breath! I used probably a lot more cheddar cheese than the recipe called for but I never measure that stuff out. There could never be too much cheese!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tried this recipe and after reading all the reviews, decided less butter the better and made some of my own variations to the recipe.  Instead of using butter to saute, I just used Smart Balance spray to coat the fry pan.

I made my pie crustless to save a few calories.  I used chopped onion, spinach (less than the recipe called for, I used only a half a cup cooked down).  Because I had seen it used in a quiche at a local diner, I added diced tomatoes for a variation.

Also, I used less milk as I was making it crustless and didn't want it to be watery.  I only used a 1/4 cup of mile and 1/2 of fat free half and half to make it creamier.

I really liked the recipe and my Dad really enjoyed the Spinanch (and vegtable) quiche.  Said it was better than the one at the local diner.  High praise as he loves eating there!

Thanks for sharing the recipe.

Ok, this was fab!!! I made this for folks who don't count calories and its a good thing! I did not read all the reviews and about mid way got concerned about the quantities. Most def makes 2 pies, there was way too much egg and milk, cut it in half and still make 2pies easily. So really the recipe makes two pies, I did lessen the butter used all the feta on the recipe and 1/2 the cheddar. added two sliced of chopped up ham for flavor and used fresh mushrooms, a must for me. I used a very large onion and I am glad. The reviews were wild, everyone wanted the recipe, men and women. As she said its an ad lib recipe, but quantiey needs to be cut back as others say too! Will make again and again ,perhaps with a tad less butter! :D

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/768918.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this twice this week and I think it’s a great dish. The first time I only made a few changes. I used three tablespoons of butter, fat free feta, low fat cheddar, added thick cut cooked bacon, and left out the salt. I bought a 9 inch deep dish Marie Callender’s frozen pie shell and I had too much filling, so I froze what I did not use. The quiche was fantastic and it was my intention to make this a head of time for a daily breakfast dish. Yesterday I multiplied the ingredients by 1.5 thinking that it would fill two pie shells. They ended up overfilled again, but not by much. If I had left the bacon out, they probably would have been fine, but there was no way that was going to happen! I refrigerated each quiche overnight and cut them into eight pieces this morning. I wrapped each piece in foil and put them in my freezer except for what I will eat the next three days. I could easily eat 1/6 or even 1/4 of the pie, but I am working on portion control and I use more expensive ingredients since almost everything that I used was organic or “clean”. I estimate that I got my cost per slice down to under $1.50 each.

I LOVED this! I used this recipe as a base for my first ever quiche! I added 4 cloves of garlic (we really like garlic at our house), used fresh spinach, and omitted the mushrooms. I added precooked bacon instead, and it was great! I also used 4oz of mozarella and 4oz of shredded mild cheddar for the cheese mix. The feta added a great taste as well! 
I always play with spices, so in the egg mixture I added a little red pepper flakes, basil, and oregano. Thank you so much for the great recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The only reason I gave 4 rather than 5 stars is because of the portioning of the recipe. I made as directed however, I split it between two regular 9 inch pie plates because I don't have a deep dish pan and I'm glad I did. (especially since we now have left-overs) I don't believe the filling would have fit in one pan and I'm not sure I would have liked the filling that thick. Splitting it worked great. The taste was delicious and the preparation was very easy. I omitted the mushrooms because I don't care for them. I think artichokes would be good or I may try substituting broccoli for the spinach next time. The onions & garlic added alot and I loved the feta cheese. Also for ease, I used the Pillsbury refrigerated pie crusts. This was my first time making quiche and I was very pleasantly surprised.

text:
Thank goodness other reviewers warned me that there is WAY too much filling for 1 quiche.  I had just the right amount for 2 regular pie crusts.  It made 2 perfect quiches following the directions above.  I did only use 1/4 cup of butter which turned out just right - not oily at all.  I also used regular feta and added a dash of tyme and basil.  I only salted and peppered once.  I also baked the crust for 5 minutes prior to cooking, but I really think it made the crust a little too brown.  You won't be dissapointed with this recipe.

text:
Fantastic!  I made this for a brunch this past weekend, and the girls devoured it.  The only thing I did different was used 8 oz. of fresh mushrooms ( I don't like canned) sauteed with the garlic & onion, and used not nearly that much butter.  I also only had a 4oz package of the feta cheese, but it still had a wonderful flavor.  I had a little too much egg/milk mixture, but not a whole lot.  Not enough for a whole other quiche.  This recipe is a keeper.  I wish I could give it 6 stars.  Thank you for sharing.

text:
This quiche was absolutely delicious, although I didn't really stay faithful to the recipe at all! I used only 2 Tbsp. butter, and sauteed the garlic and onion with a head of fresh broccoli. I also put in fresh sausage from my local farmer's market, which really made it amazing! I didn't have any feta, so I just threw in a handful of taco cheese and a couple handfuls of mozzarella. I mixed all these ingredients into the egg mixture before I added it to the pie crust. Excellent recipe - thanks!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great basic recipe for a first timer. I took several readers advise..In a nutshell this makes two quiches (add extra egg and @ 2 oz extra milk), do not add salt, squeeze excess water out of spinach, use 4 tablespoon butter, prebake crust for 5-7 minutes, chop feta into finer crumbles with knife, used sharp cheddar, I added 1 thick slice of deli ham cubed, vidalia onion, celery, cuban peppers, red peppers & green peppers. This was  a great hit and it is so easy to add your own flavors to it. It also reheats well.

text:
First time I had made quiche. Excellent and easy recipe. Would have been a 5-star, but I took others' suggestions and adjusted the ingredients. Used 3 eggs, 3/4 cup milk, 2 cloves of garlic, 3 Tbsp. of butter, 1/2 pckg of spinach, and 1/2 the cheeses. I used plain feta and sauteed fresh mushrooms with the onions and garlic. I also baked the pie crust 5 minutes before filling the shell. I forgot the salt & pepper (oops!) but never missed it!  Next time, I will reduce the butter even more and leave out the garlic (it added nothing to it). But it's definitely a keeper! I felt like a culinary expert, making this dish.

text:
This was a delicious quiche!  I followed the advice of others and halved the butter (adding a little olive oil), fresh mushrooms and instead of using 4 eggs I used 2 plus the equivalent of 2 eggs but just the whites.  My 6-yr-old daughter gobbled up two big pieces!  My only problem was that the bottom of the crust was mushy.  Next time I'll drain the spinach better, let the ingredients cool a little more before adding to the pie crust, and will also heat the crust for a few minutes before adding the mixtures.  I might even mix things up and add artichokes ...  Overall this is an easy, flavorful quiche!  Thank you!  :)

Really Delicious, but you have to substitute real mushrooms for the canned ones. It's easy enough. Just slice' em up and put them in the pan with the onions. text:
LOVED IT!!!! I am a big fan of quiche so I'm rather picky. I took other's advice and did 3 tbls of butter which is efficient. It was still a little greasy on the bottom of the crust, even after baking it in the oven for 7 minutes as the other reviewers suggested. I only could only find regular feta in the store, so I added a dash of oregano, basil, and parsley, which was yummy. I didn't have enough spinach, so at the last minute, I added ham, which ended up being my favorite part!! You MUST add ham to this! Good thing my husband and I always have those big chunks of ham in our freezer.

text:
I used half of a 10-oz package of frozen spinach, half of the Cheddar cheese, 1 tablespoon butter, 3/4 cup milk, and omitted the mushrooms. For the pie crust, I used my own recipe and baked it for 10 minutes before adding the filling and baking for another 55 minutes. The filling barely fit into my regular 9-inch pie pan.  The quiche was very tasty, and my brother, who doesn't even like spinach, enjoyed it.  Next time I will try adding crumbled sausage or diced ham, but the quiche is still delicious without meat.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I took the author's advice of adding and subtracting to my taste and found this to be a really great base recipe. I used olive oil in place of butter to saute the onion and garlic. I also added an extra clove of garlic because I'm addicted to the stuff. Instead of canned mushrooms, I opted to buy fresh, chop them finely and saute them. I pretty much eyeballed the cheese and added a few good shakes of hot sauce along with the pepper in the eggs. Put it all in a very simple crust recipe I'd found online and it was fantastic! I also realized as I was starting to fill up the pie crust that I didn't have enough room for 4 eggs and milk but that's my fault because I was using a tart dish that's probably only 8 inches. I made do with 3 eggs and 3/4 cup of milk and I didn't feel like it ended up being too dense so if your space is limited, don't worry too much about decreasing liquid.

text:
This was delicious and so easy!  I changed a lot and this recipe was very forgiving: I only used 1tbsp butter. I left out garlic. I used fresh spinach (torn into small pieces) and added broccoli. I had regular feta, so I added basil, sage, thyme, and rosemary for flavor. I only used half the feta and 3/4 the cheddar called for. I baked for 45 minutes total.  I was worried because this was my first quiche and I changed so much, but my boyfriend and I LOVED it!!! I will be making this again for sure! Maybe playing around with different veggies next time.

I used fresh spinach and fresh mushrooms, and also added a red bell pepper to the mix. i first sauteed the onions and garlic in a little butter and a touch of olive oil, and then set them aside in a bowl. then i cooked the mushrooms and red bell pepper, and cooked down the spinach. i added that to the bowl and mixed. then added the cheeses. i prepared two pie tins with crusts, spread half of the mixture in each. i used 8 eggs in total, and still only 1 cup of milk. i split that between the pies and it made the perfect amount. otherwise followed recipe as stated. thanks alot!

text:
I tried this recipe without the piecrust and, instead, mixed all the ingredients together and poured the mixture into large muffin tins.  The baking time was pretty much the same and the finished product was great.  The muffin tin idea wasn't mine.  It was actually recommended by another reviewer.  Great idea!  And each muffin makes 1 serving.  I freeze them and use them for lunches during the day.  Also, I later tried the recipe with frozen artichoke hearts (thawed and chopped) instead of spinach.  I thought it was very good -- but then I also like artichoke hearts!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The basic recipe was wonderful as other reviewers have said. The mixture of cheeses as well as textures with the onions, spinach and mushrooms was divine. The measurements were a little off (as other reviewers have said as well), this however worked to my advantage as I had to make 14 quiches for a brunch of 105, yesterday. It looked beautiful as it was being served, so thank you Bailey for sharing. Things I changed as I was working it:  Lessened the butter and added a little olive oil while sauteing the onions; Added a bouillon cube and garlic powder as I was sauteing the spinach to lessen it's moisture level; Used garlic powder instead of cloves of garlic; Did not use any extra salt as I felt that the cheese added enough saltiness to the dish and finally I pricked the defrosted pie crust with a fork before browning it in the oven and baked it for 6 minutes before adding the filling.

text:
Delicious!  This is a good basic quiche recipe, and as in the description, it is infinitely flexible.  I took what I had, canned and fresh spinach, cheddar and parmasan cheese, put those into the mix with sautéed garlic and onion, and then topped it off with slices on fresh heirloom tomato and more cheese.  I baked it for 40 minutes and let it cool atop the stove.  This quiche was better than what I can get at the local bakery, and very moist!  I would make sure you don't overcook it.

I have made this a number of times and it is great. I would, however, recommend baking the pie crust for about 8 minutes so it holds the filling better. text:
Following advice, I changed quite a bit. Used cream, not milk; about 2 cups to 4 XL eggs was the ratio. Sauteed minced onion in butter, added well drained spinach, fresh mushrooms (not canned) and some chopped, seeded tomato. Seasoned with nutmeg, salt, and white pepper. That makes 2 8" pies that serve 16, or 8 each pie. (I made this as a crustless quiche to reduce calories). Yum! Tip: Start the oven very hot, then reduce to prevent overbrowing of the top. Result was 5 stars, but I'm giving the recipe as written 3, because I had to change so much.

country:
None
text:
This was excellent. I made a few adjustments and it was a hit! Instead of butter I used about 1 tbsp of olive oil. Instead of the feta cheese I used about 1/4 cup of herb and garlic cream cheese mixed in with the onion and garlic mix. It sort of melts a bit. Then I sprinkled mozzarella cheese on top and put the quiche in the oven. This recipe also made enough for two pies so I put 4 eggs per pie and just split the spinach/onion mix in half. Very good...will definitely make again!

text:
This quiche is very good.  I doubled the recipe to have a spare quiche and I'm glad I did.  I used 10 oz. fresh spinach, sauteed, for both quiches and subbed sauteed red pepper for the mushrooms since I didn't have any.  I put in a bit less cheese, a lot less butter than was called for and one less egg (that was all I had) but it was still delicious.  We also used Sargento cheddar and bacon Bistro blend cheese.  That little bit of bacon was lovely in this dish!  I would definitely make this again.

text:
Great recipe, exceptionally flexible with ingredients which is good because I like extra cheese.  It does make 2 pies however.  I would suggest two regular 7" pies.  I tried the deep dish, but the were a little too deep.  Also I suggest to put the last layer of cheese about 10 or 15 minutes before the end as opposed to 10 or 15 after they first go in.  Also this freezes great.  I cut it into quarters and it makes a great meal when I am short on time.  Just pop it in the microwave and insta-quiche.

None
text:
Good recipe but needs some changes.  You can use little or no butter (I used PAM) to saute the onion and garlic.  1/2 c is just way too much.  I cut the eggs and milk in half or else it would've overflowed.  If you're not a fan of stronger cheeses, skip the feta and just use cheddar.  You can definitely change the other ingredients to your taste - mushrooms, onions, tomatoes, etc.  Very adaptable recipe.  Also, pre-bake the crust 5 minutes to prevent a soggy bottom.

I only gave this one 4 stars because of a few hiccups I had while making...the taste is 5 stars!  I found that the deep dish crust wasn't large enough to hold all the ingredients and spilled out leaving only half the egg mixture.  

Still turned out delicious and the feta was a great surprise to my guests that tried this!  I would almost say that you could split this mixture between two crusts and it would be great.  I'll have to try that the next time I make this.  

Also, for those that aren't fond of the bitterness of spinach (like me! LOL)...this recipe is perfect since it balances it out so nicely!  The only other thing I might change is using less butter :o)

text:
I thought this quiche was good, but a bit too heavy in my opinion. I like something a bit lighter, but that is me.  That being said my family said it was excellent overall so I will give it 4 stars. I made a few changes: I used 2 cloves of garlic, not three. I used fresh mushrooms (would never use canned) and I sauted them with onion and garlic in butter. Called for a stick of butter, which I used, but I think that could be cut in half easily or not used at all--maybe olive oil would be just as good and less fattening. I also used regular feta cheese, not fond of all that garlic. My dish only fit half the egg mixture called for.  Maybe I will use 3 eggs and less milk next time--not sure? I guess if you have a bigger dish--10 inch-that might work. I cooked the 15 minutes, then topped with Cheddar, and cooked only about 30 minutes more in my oven.

text:
Great recipe. I made four changes in preparation of this dish. First, I used only 2 tablespoons of olive oil to saute the onion and garlic instead of the recommended 1/2 cup of butter. Second, my market only carried 4oz containers of feta cheese so I used that amount instead of the recommended 6oz. Third, my husband is not a big fan of mushrooms so I omitted the them from the recipe. Finally, since I am a "cheesehead" from Wisconsin and have access to lots of types of cheese, I chose to top the quiche with a 4 year aged white cheddar. The quiche was wonderful. Thank you for this recipe.

text:
I was scared because I have never made quiche before.  I acidentally made a couple errors but I think it actually helped the recipe.  I did the spinach mixture as intructed but found that I could not get the egg mixture to seep into the spinach while it was in the pie shell.  I ended up taking the spinach mixture out and combining with egg mixture in separate bowl then putting back in pie shell. Worked out much better.  I also reversed the baking instructions.  I baked for 40 min then put the cheese on top and baked for 15 min.  It came out perfect. The only thing my family suggested is next time I make two.  They wanted seconds and it was gone.

text:
I chose to make this recipe due to so many rating it so highly. It was the best quiche I've ever made and I've made many. I didn't use all that butter, just enough olive oil to cook the onions and mushrooms which were fresh. I couldn't buy the herb garlic Fetta so I used a herb one. Like other reviewers I found the egg mixture too much to fit in my large quiche dish. I think 2 eggs and much less milk would have been fine. The only change I'd really suggest is to make a double batch as everyone fought over the leftovers. Delicious and thanks for the best recipe I've found on this site.

text:
Yum!  As stated this is a VERY forgiving recipe. I made several changes that worked very well: 2 tbs butter instead of 8 tbs.; I wilted fresh spinach--I eyeballed the amount as I wanted a lot of spinach; did not use a crust; did not use the mushrooms, but added in a cup of chopped leftover ham; only had plain feta on hand; used soymilk. I had enough for 2 so I used a glass pie dish and a metal 9-in cake pan. These cooked up much faster than the recipe called for and were set after cooking for about 35 minutes as opposed to total time of 50-55 min. called for in the recipe. Very yummy!

text:
I decided to make this on a whim...and didn't have all the called for ingredients but it still turned out GREAT!  I used the eggs, milk, spinach, onions, garlic and butter.  Added 7 sliced of precooked turkey bacon (diced) and diced red bellpepper (sauteed with the onions and garlic).  Then I just mixed everything together into one bowl tossed in a couple of handfuls of grated cheese, mixed well and poured into my pre-baked pie shell (I pre-baked it for 5 mins).  I cooked uncovered for 15 mins then tented some foil lightly over the top of the pie until the last 5 mins - removed to allow the top to brown jut a bit more and it came out perfect!  My friend asked if I bought it!  This is a great recipe for whatever you have on hand.  A keeper for sure!

country:
None
text:
I only gave this 3 stars because I had to bake it for over an hour for it to be done which played havoc with my afternoon tea schedule. The flavor was good. I made several variations to the recipe based on previous reviews - used 1 tbsp. butter and 1 tbsp. olive oil to saute garlic and onion; used only 6 oz. of shredded cheddar cheese; no additional salt because the feta was so salty; only used 1/2 cup of milk and only used 1 egg plus 4 egg whites because I don't like the flavor of egg yolk. Definitely put this in a deep dish pie plate and allow plenty of time to bake. It is a good recipe with tweaking. It tastes just like spanokopita (Greek spinach pie).

text:
This was super easy and my first pie that doesn't go from the freezer to the oven.  I skipped the mushrooms, used olive oil instead of butter (1/4 cup) and I put foil over the crust to prevent burning. I used 3 eggs and 1 egg white but the egg mixture overflowed so I'll reduce the milk next time.  I also plan to do a better job of draining the spinach because I suspect that the additional moisture accounted for less room for the egg mixture.  I brought this to Thanksgiving dinner and they loved it! It is a bit heavy with all that cheese so I think I'll try some low fat cheddar next time.

text:
Just made this yesterday and it turned out great! I made a few changes with the cheeses. I used Havarti Dill Cheese instead of the Feta, which has a sweet, creamy dill flavor to it and works great with the spinach. And instead of adding the cheddar after 15 minutes I used crumbled Brie, which made a great crust on top. Also, I didn't add the mushrooms and the top of the quiche was pretty big. I'd imagine you'd need to cut some milk or cheese to accommodate for a standard pie dish. Definitely a keeper - thanks for sharing!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Outstanding!  I made many a quiche with my mother, but this was my first on my own. I made a few adjustments for what I had on hand and my own preferences but this recipe gave me a great guideline... I used mozzarella vs swiss, shallots/garlic vs onion, added grated carrots, 50:50 low fat milk to half and half vs milk alone.  Also, I left the butter out entirely sauteeing the shallot/garlic in a tbsp olive oil, and I used 3 whites and 2 yolks.  One thing I have to say is that I followed others advice and attempted to split the mixture into two pies... NOT a good idea.  My quiches, although they taste great, are pretty thin.  One big fat quiche would be more presentable for a potluck then a skinny minnie two.  Thanks again!!!

text:
Great and easy recipe! This was my first quiche, and it turned out beautifully, with some modifications. I only used 1 tbsp butter and 1 tbsp olive oil to saute the onions and garlic. I used 3 eggs and 1/2 cup of milk. This fit really well into one 9-inch deep dish pie crust. I also only used about 1/2 cup of shredded cheese within the quiche and sprinkled just a bit more on top to bake off. Final product wasn't greasy or oily, but just perfect! Can't wait to make again.

Very good quiche...and very forgiving, just like it said!  I didn't have mushrooms on hand, so I omitted them.  I used only 1 TBS of butter with olive oil to saute the garlic. I added a small chopped onion and 1/2 a chopped red bell pepper.  I had a 5 oz. container of regular low fat feta, and added Wildtree Herbs' Garlic & Herb Blend to that.  I prefer a crustless quiche, so I baked this in my Pampered Chef round baker.  It came out excellent!  I'll definitely do this again!  I used low fat versions of cheese and milk.  Great, calcium rich recipe.  Thanks!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Sooooooooooo good... a few changes, though. I used only 3 tbsp unsalted butter (plenty!), a large yellow onion, some fresh spinach in addition to frozen (added this at the end just before pouring into crust), only 4oz feta, added 2-3oz ricotta (!!), fresh mushrooms, SKIM milk, kosher salt (always in cooking), added all the cheddar in with the mixture and topped (before any baking) with grated Parmesan instead, AND... drumroll, I combined both mixtures BEFORE pouring into the crusts (I also used 2 deep dish crusts for this recipe). This was absolutely amazing... I will be making time and time again!!

text:
I'm not a big "egg" dish person, but I tried this recipe for a family breakfast at Christmas, and it was wonderful!  I didn't have any feta on hand, so I substituted gruyere that I had in the freezer, along with the  cheddar cheese.  I cut back on the butter by a couple of tablespoons and used a traditional quiche/tart pan for baking.  The presentation was beautiful, and it tasted even better the next morning.  I'll be adding this recipe to my favorites.  Thanks, Bailey!

text:
What a great recipe. I followed it pretty close and used some of the suggestions left by other cooks. I added brocolli along with the spinach. I used one 10oz box of frozen spinach and about 1 1/2 cups of brocolli. I used swiss cheese instead of the feta and mixed it in with the spinach/brocolli mix before placing in the pie shell. I made two, one for me and one for my mother and she even ate a piece for breakfeast. This recipe is so easy and you can use your creativity to make it personalized.

text:
I've misplaced my favorite quiche recipe, but this one looked similar enough to try and am I glad I did!  It was delicious and the texture was exactly to my liking.  I changed things up a bit...using chopped broccoli instead of spinach[tho I love it with spinach!] and swiss in place of the feta.  It didn't last the night!!!  Luckily, I got one piece before my 2 teenagers devoured the entire thing!  I don't suppose I'll need to turn the kitchen upside down looking for my old quiche recipe, huh?  I'm going to try this again next week with crumbled sausage in place of the spinach and add green and red peppers/monterey jack/cheddar.  Mmmm.

text:
I get so many compliments on this recipe, it is spectacular.  I cut way back on the butter, and use fresh sliced mushrooms instead of canned/jarred. make sure to get all the water out of the spinach.  Also i dont like eggy quiches, so i only use enough egg and milk to barely cover the top.  Make this quiche for guest, and they all of a sudden think your a brilliant cook.

text:
Great recipe!!  I really enjoyed this.  I used reduced fat feta.  I just eyeballed how much cheese I wanted in it and I'm pretty sure I didn't come close to putting in as much as what the recipe called for.  Also, I mixed all the cheese in instead of sprinkling it on top.  I also used fresh mushrooms which I sauteed with the onions.  Finally, I put 3/4 of a packet of spinach.  Great recipe!  Thanks for sharing.

text:
Taste wise this recipe definitely deserves 5 stars, but because of some mishaps during the preparation I only gave it 4 stars.  I wish I read the reviews before I made it.  I agree with others-1 stick of butter is too much.  My biggest problem, however, was that I couldn't fit all of the egg mixture into my pie crust (it was a 9 inch deep dish as the recipe called for).  Not only did it make a mess in my kitchen, but my oven is a mess too.  Then when I had to add the cheddar cheese the quiche overflowed into my oven even more.  I couldn't even add the entire amount of cheese.  I'm so glad the quiche tasted so good-it made me forget about the preparation disaster!

text:
What a great recipe!!! I decided to use 2 tablespoons of butter due to the comments made by previous reviewers, as well as omitting the shredded cheddar on top of the quiche, and it came out perfectly. The cheddar inside the quiche was enough for my family. Also for those of you, like myself, who refuse to season to taste with raw egg products...I used 1/2 tsp salt & 1/8 tsp pepper. Fits comfortably in a 9-inch DEEP DISH pie shell. All-in-all, a wonderful meal-time treat!

text:
I loved it. 
After reading reviews, I used very little butter to saute the garlic and onion. 
Someone suggested pre baking the pie crust a bit for crispness, great idea! You might need a bit of foil for crust edges near the end of baking, but worth it.
 I must have a true deep dish pie plate. Many reviewers found the filling was too much for one quiche. I found it was the perfect amount. 
And I added cayenne, to kick it up a bit.
Oh, and it freezes beautifully. Whole pie, or frozen by the slice.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Have made this recipe several times, the only change is using FRESH spinach instead of frozen. The frozen has way too much water in it, even after defrosting and pressing out the moisture. Only a 1/4 cup of butter, instead of 1/2 cup because the first time I made it, it tasted like butter!! Fresh mushrooms (6 medium) instead of canned, And plain feta. All the ingredients were mixed in a bowl then placed in the crust because the first time, the egg didn't mix well with "dry ingredients" as the recipe instructs. Basically the fresh vegetables and less butter reduced the moisture and also I prefer fresh over processed.

text:
This recipe is delicious! I made some of the changes recommended by others such as reduced butter (used only 2 Tbls). I had a fresh crust which I pre-baked for 5 minutes. Added some baked ham and a bit more feta than called for.  I reduced the amount of cheddar cheese by one quarter. The baking dish was a bit deeper than most so all the ingredients DID manage to fit into one dish ....barely.  I allowed some time for the wet ingredients to soak into the spinach mixture for awhile. Tasted great!!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
I have been making this recipe for years. As the years went on I have adjusted it to my own liking. I only do about a tbsp or two of butter. I saute fresh spinach not frozen in a pan with butter, garlic, chopped onion and bacon. Once it's all cooked I add in the feta and only cook a few minutes longer. I place it in to the pie crust then top with 5 eggs scrambled with about 3/4 cups of milk and I also add the shredded cheddar cheese to the egg mixture as well. I bake for 30 minutes, pull out and top with more shredded cheddar cheese then continue to bake until fully cooked.

Display Name:
Mama Leone

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first time I made this recipe I followed it to a T, including using an unbaked frozen deep pie crust shell. The contents were too much despite using a deep dish pie shell. 

The second time, I partially baked a fresh pie shell, using a new truly deep pie plate.No overage. I could not find Herb and Garlic Feta Cheese, so I added a small shallot to the sautéing onion and garlic. When it was time for Herb and Garlic Feta Cheese , I improvised by using plain Feta and mixed Italian Herbs into it  before I adding it to the sautéd onion mixture. 
Then adding then cheddar cheese, I used 1/3 cup more. ( I did have a larger pie plate this time) All of this ingredients were mixed with the spinach. The egg mixture had equal parts of heavy cream and milk added. In order to get a more thorough mixture, I added the egg, milk mixture directly into my skillet. Doing that step really allowed all of the ingredients to really thoroughly mix. It worked out well. My husband told me that this quiche was my best one so far! ( I have made 4 in the last month-2 Quiche Lorraine and 2 Spinach Quiche )

One of the best quiches I've ever made -- and a wonderful vegetarian option for picky eaters. I made a few changes which I think made it wonderful: 
- Left out the mushrooms and doubled the spinach
- Replaced the feta cheese with parmesan cheese
- Used sharp white cheddar on top 
- Reduced the butter to 6 Tbs. 

DELICIOUS!

text:
On the whole, good and easy recipe. I followed some suggestions from other reviews, namely to split the recipe into two quiches and to pre-bake the shells for a few minutes to get a crispy bottom instead of soggy. These two together meant a shorter baking time by about 15 minutes. Fortunately, I checked, but my pastry was overdone (dark brown, crunchy), and the filling was on the edge. It was still good, but next time I'll maybe not pre-bake the shells. Otherwise, the family said it's a keeper.

Did not use butter, just a bit of oil to saute the onion. No garlic. I used bacon but ham would be fine too.

5 eggs, cup and a half of swiss ('m sure another cheese would be fine).  I started with a cup of cheese then sprinkled an additional 1/2 cup 15-20 minutes into baking. Added 1/4 tsp of nutmeg which I love with eggs/milk which accents the custard so well.

All in all, a great recipe to use as a basis for an adaptable quiche.

Yikes, hit return and it posted.... So, here goes:  I preferred using fresh ingredients. Added super to the flavor but I should have squeezed the moisture from the fresh microwaved spinach and the pan fried fresh mushrooms. I would also bake the pie crust for 15 minutes empty to give it a head start for the wet ingredients. I used skim milk because that’s all we had at the time....no, no, not ever again. I’d rather use whole milk or even half and half. I used baking merely as a guideline and found it took longer.  I will definitely make this again and try it without changing the authors recipe.

text:
I wanted something that tasted on the idea of a Greek spinach pie, and this satisfied that craving! I actually made this crustless, something I prefer lately (easier, lighter and less calories). I halved the recipe, and used cooking spray on a 9" tin pie plate. I had a 5 oz bag of baby spinach that I wanted to use up, so I wilted that in a little olive oil for about 5 min, adding a little salt and pepper. I only used about 2 tblsp of butter to saute the onion; 1/4 cup in the halved version would have been way too much for me, anyway. I did leave out the mushrooms. I believe I read the recipe wrong and added too much cheddar to the quiche, not realizing some was reserved for the top. I still put a little on top, along with a sprinkling of Romano cheese. Maybe because it was in a smaller pan, but mine was ready in 25 min after the initial 15 min baking time. Thanks for this excellent recipe Bailey, which I'll surely make again!!

This is such a delicious and versatile recipe. Thr only adjustments ive made is cutting the butter way back, like half. It does make more than one deep dish though so I've ended up adding a bit more milk and an extra egg to even out the 2 pies I end up with. I could literally lick the dish with this recipe.

country:
None
text:
Great recipe!  Wonderful blend of flavors.  This is the first time I made a quiche with garlic.  That kicked it up a few notches.  I only had cream on hand.  As recommended by other reviewers I reduced the butter by half.  I did not pre-bake the pie shell.  With the filling in the shell, I baked it for 20 minutes in a preheated 425 oven.  Without opening the door, reduced temperature to 375 and continued baking for 15-20 additional minutes.  Enough filling to make two 9 inch pies.  My vegetarian friends loved it.  But next time, I’ll use Half & Half and make it with  bacon and fresh mushrooms.  Very flexible and delicious recipe.

Display Name:
Savanna S.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm glad I read through the comments before making this dish! To start, I baked both of my frozen pie shells for 8 minutes to prevent the bottom of the pie crust from becoming soggy. Be sure to stab the crust with fork before baking to prevent bubbling.  I also took people's advice and used only 1 tbsp of butter which was perfect, and I fried my fresh mushrooms in with my onions and spinach. Quantity-wise, I varied things slightly: I used about 8 oz of spinach rather than the suggested 10 oz which was still plenty for a spinach lover, 200g of herb and garlic feta - an extra ounce than suggested, 1 tbsp of minced garlic from a jar in the fridge rather than fresh, and 1 extra egg so 5 total. This recipe makes TWO full quiches, even when using a deep dish pie crust. Thankfully my grocery store sells them in two's, so I had an extra one on hand and was able to use all the filling across two pie shells that resulted in two full quiches. Great recipe. A very tasty, savoury dish that I will definitely make again!

text:
This is a FANTASTIC recipe, but don't expect the proportions to fit at all.
We take out the mushrooms because of allergies, but beyond that you really only need like half the butter or it seeps into the crust and makes it liquid. Additionally, I've never been able to make all the eggs fit, so I halve that, too, because personally I prefer more substance than egg to my quiches.
We've been making this recipe in our family for a good number of years and have found that this works best for us, and it tastes amazing even when microwaved, making it a fantastic thing to prepare in advance for a long week.

text:
I believe it's the feta that sets this apart! Flavor is excellent, and house smelled so good preparing it! Used a frozen deep-dish pie crust, did a 5-min pre-bake on the crust but recommend 10. Also, wrapped crust edge with tinfoil half-way through. I avoid lactose so went with macadamia nut milk (higher fat/protein and non-distinct flavor, so no unintentional flavor imparted). Used a bit less spinach than it called for. A hit even for the kid (near-adult) who doesn't like spinach!

I only used about 2 tablespoons of butter, rather than 1/2 cup and I omitted the feta,  and added bacon.  It was amazing. 

I read several reviews that indicated that this recipe had a good bit of left over filling for one crust,  so I used 6 eggs rather than 4. and increased the milk to 1 1/2 cups.  Doing this, I had enough filling for 2 deep dish pies, rather than one.

text:
Here are my changes, I multiplied everything by 1.5 and that made a perfect amount for 2 crust. I only added 1.25 cups of half and half instead if 1.5 cups of milk and really squeezed out the liquid from the spinach I steamed before returning to the empty pot, through the cheese in with the spinach and mixed that, the cheese melted in. Then threw in the butter and garlic mix and mixed that with the spinach cheese. Then I mixed the eggs and half and half, beat that together well. Added that to the spinach cheese mix and stired that up well and then spooned that into the crust.

userID:
7086736
Display Name:
EllieB
isPro:

4

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I changed this up a bit after not being able to find a quiche recipe that called for less cheese and no crust. I sauteed the onion in 2 tsp of butter and added 3 cloves of chopped garlic. After mixing the onion, garlic and mushrooms together I blended in about 5 ounces of canned salmon. I used four eggs and 2 cups of half and half, and whisked  in 1/4 cup of flour, 1 scant cup of mozzarella, plain feta plus about 1/4 tsp of dill and doubled the black pepper; sprayed a deep dish pie pan with cooking spray and mixed all the ingredients together. About 5 minutes before the cook time was up I frosted it with pre-cooked  Ore-Ida frozen combination mashed potato and cauliflower  mix and continued cooking til the top was light brown. Came out somewhere between a quiche and Shepards pie. Of course it would've been good without the topping but it did make up for the lack of crust.

text:
So like many, I neglected to read the notes about the butter, etc, but I only used 2 T anyway.  I also browned the mushrooms after rinsing them and patting them dry.  Once the onions started to go to translucent, I added the mushrooms to make sure the metallic canned taste didn’t ruin my quiche.  I never buy canned anything, but for my first try I decided to go with the recipe and then adjust if I do it again.  I didn’t use all of the egg mixture, it just wouldn’t fit and I bake the quiche on a baking sheet in case it boiled over, which it did not.  I won’t know til tomorrow if the oiliness is there, but it sure looks and smells amazing!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was a good starting point, but as it was my first time making quiche, I relied heavily on other reviews.  I chopped and fried six slices of bacon, and used the grease to saute the onions, garlic, and probably about 1/2 Tablespoon basil (I couldn't find the garlic and herb feta).  I used regular feta.  I also sauteed about a pound fresh spinach in butter to remove the water.  I had two deep dish pie crusts, which I cooked for about 8 minutes empty before I added the spinach/cheese mixture.  I also used 3/4 cup milk and 6 eggs.   I did not add any more butter/oil other than what remained in the cooked spinach after I drained it, and the grease from the bacon.  It turned out really yummy.  I will make it again!  Next time I might try adding some sun dried tomatoes.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very yummy recipe... Also very forgiving and very versatile. I have made this many times with success. Tonight I omitted the mushrooms, kept the butter at 1/2-cup (which was still plenty), didn't measure the cheddar - just added handfuls till it looked "cheesy enough". My feta was plain so I threw in a tsp of Italian seasoning. I doubled the filling which made three 9" (store-bought deep dish) pies. I also reduced the milk to 3/4-cup. Sky is the limit with combinations you could make... bacon, mushroom, peppers, zucchini, etc!! Baked in covection at 350 for 15-min, added cheese, then baked 30-min more. Delish!

text:
This is an expensive dish to make and for there to be an error like I found was cruel. The recipe calls for 1/2 cup of butter. I made 2 quiches so therefore used 1 cup of butter. I thought It seemed excessive but forged ahead. The most  it should have had in the ingredients was 3 tbsp of butter. I had butter dripping out of the pie plate when I took it out of the oven.  Needless to say, it was almost inedible. May decide to throw the extra one out. I would have expected allrecipes to test it first. Not sure I will try another recipe from them.

I really liked this recipes but made a few changes that helped a lot, thank you reviewers. I skip the butter and used just enough olive oil to cook everything down. I also use fresh spinach and mushrooms, just a personal preference. I also use shallots instead of onions and am very happy with the results. I also use just enough milk to mix the eggs. Great recipe and all I did was make some minor changes to suit our house, great stuff and a delicious quiche.

text:
I have made this so many times, it's time for a review. It's my go to recipe for family brunch. I use 3 eggs and 3/4 cups of milk and don't use cheese on top. I sometimes use fresh spinach and mushrooms that I sauté with the onions and extra garlic. In a pinch I use canned mushrooms and frozen spinach - both are good. The key cheat is the Mediterranean flavored feta I buy. My family also likes it with red pepper flakes.

city:

country:
None
text:
This was delicious! I've never had feta cheese and was a bit nervous about trying it, so I used ricotta instead. I took others' advice and increased the eggs to 8, used a 10 oz bag of fresh spinach and kept all the other ingredients the same. I also used two deep dish pie dishes instead of one. Lastly, after pre-baking the shells for 10 minutes, I put a small layer of spinach and cheese on the bottom of each one to prevent any potential sogginess from occurring, then baked for about 5 minutes longer than recommended. This turned out excellent and my husband and son loved it!

This is the best quiche I have ever tasted and will be making it for Easter lunch.

My whole family loves this recipe. It has been my go-to quiche for years. I solved the overflow problem by switching to a deep dish pie pan. I also recently cut the butter in half and no one noticed a difference.

region:

country:
None
text:
This quiche is awesome!! I've made it twice in one week. :) The first time, completely as written and the second with subtle tweeks to the quantity of a few ingredients. Now, I like butter, but this recipe calls for A LOT of it so the second time I cut way down, to 1 TBSP and I thought it still tasted great. Also, it was a lot of filling and not a lot of egg mixture comparatively. So, the second time I made two quiches keeping the same quantity of filling split between the two and doubled the egg mixture. This also prevented the filling from overflowing like it did the first time. The recipe as is is fantastic. Definitely try it. The tweeks I made were simply to suit my waistline and tastebuds. Enjoy.

I didn't use butter, I used fresh mushrooms (8oz) and spinach 1/2 large bag), 1/2 small onion, didn't use the herbal feta ( can never find that in my grocers) I used a small amount of cheddar, I used egg beaters and only 1/4 cup of milk, which I probably shouldn't have because it had a bit too much liquid. I added coarse garlic powder. I also put about 3 pieces of cooked bacon in it so my hubby would eat it!

 I didn't think my hubby would eat it because it was spinach, but he ate quite a bit of it! So thanks for the recipe!

text:
I did a healthy version of this recipe. I used lite margarine 1 1/2 Tbsp. to sauté  the onion and garlic for a few minutes, I added  the sliced mushrooms, then the chopped spinach for a few more minutes, till it wilted.  I used half the cheese it called for and I did  3 eggs and 1/2 cp. low-fat milk. I baked for 45 min. at 375F and it was amazing! Another good tip from a reviewer: Before filling the pie crust with the quiche filling FIRST brush the pie crust bottom with egg and bake it for 5-8 min. to avoid soggy bottom crust.

city:

country:

text:
Used the recipe, and made these changes: no canned mushrooms (never buy them)but there were a couple of fresh small  ones left in the fridge, so used them. No herbed feta, but had plain feta so added about a teaspoon of fresh chives from the garden.  Shredded my own cheddar (no packaged shredded cheese if I can help it). Added 2 strips chopped bacon for the men, and a few sundried tomatoes.  After sautéing the ingredients, including the mushrooms, was aghast at the amount of butter so drained out a good 1/4 of a cup and discarded it.  The remainder of the recipe was as written.  Quiche was GREAT! My addition of sun dried tomatoes not a good fit but the small amount of bacon perfect.  Too much liquid with 4 extra large eggs, so it spilled over onto my cookie sheet and had to be blotted up.  Will make again, but not w/ that much butter (maybe try a quarter stick?) and use a little less milk, and just large eggs.  Butter and overflow the reason it didn't get 5 stars but yummy!

I added 8 oz of cooked, chopped chicken and substituted creole seasoning for salt and pepper.  I also could not find the garlic and herb feta so I used regular feta cheese with a dash of garlic.  One should note that when adding extra ingredients you will have enough for two pies instead of one.  So I made two.  I divided the spinach mixture evenly among the 2 pie shells and I just added two more eggs and a bit more milk to the egg mixture.  I ended up with 2 perfect spinach and chicken quiches.

text:
This was delicious. I used fresh mushrooms can sauté with onions. Divided batter into muffin tins, baked then froze them. They reheated great! My family loved them.

the measurements on this recipe are a little off. If baked as per recipe, the quiche will be too oily and will not fit into one deep pie dish.


a few variations to lower the fat content,  margarine instead of butter and halved it, per everyone's suggestions. I used skim milk, and I used egg whites instead of eggs. I also reduced the cheddar a bit, an use swiss. Also, I used fresh mushrooms and sauted them with the onions and garlic. made mine without a pie shell.

text:
Followed the instructions but substituted the 4.5oz of mushrooms for 4.5oz of ham. However, i think it made the quiche a little too salty (especially cuz feta cheese is also salty by nature) so i would recommend putting less ham and eliminating the salt ingredient completely if you are using ham. The ingredients were enough to fill a 9" pyrex glass pie dish; not sure why other reviewers say it is too much. I made my pie crust using Ruth's Grandma's Pie Crust recipe on this site- it is excellent and i highly recommend it!!! (Light, slightly flakey and just right... I could eat the crust by itself for a meal haha)

userID:
17177918
Display Name:
Brittany Britto
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was able to make 2 quiche with this recipe. I too changed it up thanks to other reviews and made up a bit of my own recipe, using pre frozen crusts. I used about 2 teaspoons of olive oil to sauté the onion and garlic, then later added 1/4 cup of butter before adding in the spinach and cheese. This helps it not stick to the pan while folding the cheeses in. I used a 1/2 cup cheddar cheese and 6 oz. feta (since size-wise, that's all that was available at the store). I used 3/4 cup of milk and 4 eggs. Once you have spooned in the spinach cheese mixture into the pan and pour over the egg, I would recommend softly stirring the egg mixture into the spinach/cheese mixture. The first time I just let it sink in by itself which resulted in far more egg up top, which is fine if that's what you prefer. I topped it off with sprinkles of cheddar, Romano and Parmesan cheese (no measurement/just what I thought would taste good). Turned out great! I made the first batch for my job, and it was gone by the end of the day. My little brother (who can be picky) and my boyfriend (who is a critique in his own right) both really enjoyed it for breakfast, lunch, snack, dinner. It's great to refrigerate and heat up later. I'll be freezing one for a tough week when a great breakfast is needed!

For 1 - 9" deep dish pie crust:
6 eggs
1/2 tsp each coriander, paprika, Turmeric , garam Masala
1/2 tsp black pepper
1/4 tsp ground cumin

Used goat milk instead of regular milk.

Used sheep's milk feta and goat cream cheese

Pre bake  pie crust before filling.

Next time: Cover with aluminum foil towards end of cooking to prevent burning  crust.

text:
a great combination for a satisfying dish ( the best during breakfast with some plain mixed greens with or without homemade dressing, or a fruit). although, go for alternating healthier choice and still keep flavourful. alternate frozen spinach with fresh organic spinach and saute it with the butter mixture for extra 2 minutes and it will soften jist like the frozen kind, use 1/4 of butter vs 1/2 cup and dont not! alternate for margarine, trust me scientifically proven butter is a better choice for a fat choice vs margarine( created fake substitute like rubber ). add a drizzle of olive oil at the end when niced all ingredients before adding to the pie shell. alternate portobello or other fresh mushroom vs canned mushrooms for higher nutritional content value. trust me just add the egg mixture with the spinach mixture and pour all together into the pie vs doing it separately , and if you want add the cheese also with it inside at the top. and this will make the quiche cook faster within 45 mins or max 50

I've made the recipe several times. Originally, as written, and know, as stated, it's a great starting point. There was one day where we were craving quiche and we needed to make more then one but I only had enough spinach for one. What's a girl to do?
I substituted a can of seasoned collard greens and we may never use spinach again!! Theres no cookong down, no defrosting, just open up a can, drain it and you are good to go! watch adding any extra salt though. It just seems to add that extra depth of flavor beyond just spinach.

text:
Great, easy recipe. Though I made a few modifications, I would think it is very tasty as written, too.

I made this got a wedding shower, so I used two shallow pie crusts instead of one deep. Used only half an onion and skipped mushrooms for husband's taste. I used half the butter and put the pie crustsin the oven for five minutes before filling it, based on other suggestions.

Changes I would like to try next time are: modifying ratio of egg mixture to spinach mix (more egg), skipping cheddar on top (would look more sophisticated without it), or putting the cheddar on in the last ten minutes.

userID:

Display Name:
Barb Johnson
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3414499.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good basic recipe and the whole family loved it....but there's a problem in the directions.
  After sauteing the garlic, onions, spinach and mushrooms in butter(and half the butter is plenty)  and adding the cheeses to that hot mixture.....
DO NOT add that to the pie crust before adding the beaten eggs and milk custard mix. 
  The melted cheeses make the filling mix a cohesive glob that was very hard to mingle with the custard mix in the pie shell without destroying the bottom of the pie shell.,
  Mix the sauteed filling with the custard base in a bowl and then pour into the ready pie shell.
  And do use a deep dish so there's room for all that luscious custard and filling. 
   Excellent flavor!
Review:

5

text:
this turned out well with rave reviews from DH.  I did reduce butter to 2 T to saute fresh baby spinach and fresh white mushrooms.  I made one quiche with a Pillsbury pie crust (for DH) and the other one (for me) in a sweet potato crust (I layered thin slices of sweet potato on a greased pie plate, baked it for 20 minutes in 375 degrees, before adding quiche filling). Both were amazing.  This is a keeper.

text:
On a scale of 1 to 10 I rate this a solid 8.5.  Cooking time for me at 34 minutes was good.  Cool down period of 10-12 minutes is a MUST.  Next time I will use even LESS salt than is called for, if any at all.  The cheese has more than enough.  Be sure to completely drain the water from the spinach and mushrooms.  I figured $2.10 per serving times six servings.  With a small salad and warm bread it's a very healthy and tasty alternative to the fast food joints.  Easy and fun to make.  I would make it again.

text:
This is a good baseline recipe.  I just throw in whatever I have for veggies on hand.  Onions,  garlic, Broccoli, carrots, spinach, you can even throw meat in there if you wanted.  But you get the idea,  throw in what you like.  I lightly coat my crust before filling with Dijon Mustard, and bake till fluffy (about 5-7 mins),  then fill,  then bake again per these instructions.   I also like to add a little Swiss in there.  But again,  this recipe is great to use as a baseline and make it your own.  :)

text:
I have used variations of the recipe for 3 or 4 years now.  Several substitutions include; using fresh spinach when in season,  making 2 regular 9 inch quiches with this recipe (rather than the deep dish), leaving left out the mushrooms.  I have used different flavors of feta....so many choices!

Couple of must haves...1) a pan under the quiche when cooking, otherwise your oven is a mess 2) I tend to cook a bit longer to brown the cheese 3)make more than 1 because there are no left overs!

I used fresh spinach and mushrooms.  The mushrooms I add at the same time as the onions and garlic so that they are appropriate softness. country:
None
text:
After reading all the reviews on this recipe I also tweaked it.  I used 12 oz fresh spinach, sautéed in small amt of olive oil,  drained and squeezed the liquid out.  4 large brown fresh mushrooms cut into pieces.  I sautéed the onions in "two" tbsp butter, then added the garlic and the mushrooms until soft.  Then I added the spinach and the cheeses.  I used Gorgonzola instead of the Feta and I used half swiss and half white cheddar cheese.   I poured the mixture into my oiled quiche dish (not deep dish) and added the milk and egg mixture.  It fit beautifully in my quiche dish.  The result was yummy!   I like quiche because we use it for "take to work" lunches the next day.    Will make again!

I have made spinach and feta quiche before, and I liked this recipe as it was very forgiving, as suggested in the recipe. I didn't use mushrooms as I didn't have any, and used pre-prepared frozen pastry as I couldn't find pie crust. Was flavourful with the onions and garlic even without added flavour in the feta. text:
Excellent recipe, hubby said its the best quiche I've ever made! Only used 1 Tbsp butter (a whole stick would have been way too much), omitted the mushrooms and used fresh spinach instead of frozen (just sauteed until wilted in skillet after onions and garlic were soft). Also, plain feta instead of the flavored kind...the feta makes this! It gives it a really yummy, salty kick. Will definitely be making this again, and probably two at a time next time (we ate the whole dish in one sitting, and quiche is one of those "better when leftover" kind of dishes to me!) Very yummy, thanks for the recipe!

text:
I made this quiche for Good Friday because I needed a good meatless alternative. Only big modification was use of half and half instead of milk because I had some I needed to use up before it had to be thrown out--waste not want not. I also used plain feta, 4 oz, instead of herbed. I mixed everything together, including all the cheddar, before I put it in the pie crust. My teenage boys could not stop eating this, and neither one is a big spinach fan. They said it was by far the best quiche I've ever made.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Oh my goodness, that was the best quiche I've ever had. I really didn't change much at all. I couldn't find anything but plain feta at the store, so that was altered. I substituted frozen spinach with fresh organic spinach, which I sautéed with garlic and butter on its own before adding to the mix. The only other thing I would change next time (and there will be a lot of next times) is to wait 25 to 30 minutes before adding the cheese on top. It came very close to burning after 25 minutes when I added it after 15, so I'll let the quiche bake longer next time before the cheese is added. Great recipe! Even my 7-year-old loved it, and he's very against new food.

I really like this recipe, and it adapted nicely, as I didn't have the feta. I used fresh spinach and fresh mushrooms following the directions I cooked on the stove top adding the spinach last. I whipped together a little cream cheese, and some ragotta cheese with the egg and cheddar cheese. Layered the pie crust with half the spinach mix and then added the egg and then the remaining egg mix and topped with cheddar cheese. I know I changed it quite a bit but I only had limited of the specified ingredients. It turned out great, next time I will try it with the feta cheese.

This is excellent quiche. It is important to drain the spinach beforehand because it makes the quiche too watery. I tried evaporating the water off in the pan with the onions and it was only partially successful. I used plain feta and topped with bacon pieces. The flavors were great together.

text:
First quiche I've ever done and it came out very yummy.  Everyone in the house loved it!  I did lessen the butter to 1/4 cup, mindful of the feedback that the quiche recipe as it stood might come out too oily.  I also used fresh spinach which I needed to wilt a batch at a time when i cooked it.  I used Kiseo, a native buffalo cheese here in the Philippines, in place of feta, and cheddar cheese.  Because the native buffalo cheese gave off some liquid, I removed most of that from the spinach mixture before I placed it in the pie crust.   I didn't salt the milk and egg mixture anymore because the spinach mixture was already salty enough.  The quiche came out really lovely. Thank you!

I loved this quiche. It reminded me of spanakopita, too. text:
I made the following changes to this recipe- fresh mushrooms instead of canned, fresh spinach instead of frozen, and 2 TBSP butter instead of 1/2 cup. The flavor was very, very good. However, the entire lower half of the quiche was soggy. When we cut into it and removed slices of the quiche, liquid oozed out from the quiche that was still in the pan. Obviously the button crust was completely soggy. So, the flavor was great but it was so soggy and wet that I cannot give it a very high rating. I may have made a mistake by using the fresh ingredients so it might have been my own personal problem instead of a flaw in the recipe!

text:
This turned out great!  I made my own pie crust, and used less butter. Put crust in for 5-7 min. beforehand to get it crispier.  I put the entire thing in a 9" cake pan with a removable bottom - this is important because the quiche filling fit perfectly in this deeper size dish. It would overflow in a regular pie pan. It's also nice aesthetically to have the removable bottom on the cake pan because you can take the quiche out of the pan, and see the crust all the way around.

text:
Completely awesome! I bought a 2 pk of deep dish pie crusts, and there is no way all of this will fit into one. Maybe if you have your own super deep dish and make your own crust it would fit. Anyway, I followed another reviewer's advice to divide the spinach mixture evenly, but make an egg/milk mixture for each and pour over top (so double the egg mixture and divide). One crust I pre-baked a few minutes, the other I didn't. No one complained of soggy crust, so I don't think it matters. I only tried one, not sure which it was. Refrigerated over night and microwaved slices the next day...wonderful!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is very forgiving. I didn't think I would like the combination of feta and cheddar, so instead i used some goat cheese, which I think has a similar tang as feta but is more mild. I also added about 1/4 lb of deli ham. I used a 9" deep dish pie crust and it was filled to the brim with a little left over, so you definitely need a deep dish crust. 

The quiche came out amazing and was even better on day 2! The only thing I did not like about the recipe  was that there is entirely WAY too much cheddar cheese reserved for topping the quiche with. I only reserved 1/4 to 1/3 of a cup of cheese to top the  quiche and it was still way too much. The result was a tough layer of cheese, rather than a soft fluffy quiche. Next time I will mix almost all of the cheese into the filling and add a light sprinkle when it has only about 10 min left to cook. I did not care for the cheese layer this recipe calls for  and if you follow the recipe exactly, you  may as well eat a melted block of cheese.

4

Display Name:
joebaker

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/183753.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great Spinach Quiche recipe!  A definite keeper in our house.  I made several changes after reading other reviews.  I made 2, easier to make a double recipe.  Prebake the pie shells for 10-15 minutes.  Saute fresh mushrooms in 3Tbl of the butter in a separate skillet while cooking the onion/garlic mixture in 5Tbl of the butter(even though I made a double recipe, I used 1/2c butter total).  When the onions were cooked, I added fresh spinach to the onion mixture (a 1lb Organic tub from Costco).  The spinach wilts quickly, keep adding a little at a time till you get all the spinach in.  When the spinach is wilted, add in the cooked mushrooms, and the cheeses as described in the original recipe.  Whisk together the eggs, milk, and seasoning in a large bowl.  Add the cooked veggie/cheese mixture to the egg mixture and stir quickly to prevent cooking the eggs.  Pour the combined mixture into the prepared pie shells and bake as directed in the original recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe.  I have tried to make this somewhat more healthier for us.  The few modifications I do is I like to brown a couple of sweet turkey sausage links then remove those onto a plate with a paper towel to get the extra grease out then add it back in later with all of the other ingredients.  I then use the same pan for the onions and garlic but I cut the butter down to 2 Tbs.  That is plenty.  I use about 3/4 of a package of fresh mushrooms diced (even though I don't like mushrooms at all, there is so much flavor in this quiche that they don't bother me).  Instead of 8 oz of cheddar, I halve that and then do about 4 oz of smoked gruyere.  That is such a great cheese in quiche.  I also use Egg Beaters instead of eggs and FF milk.  I never use a crust  and it turns out fantastic every time.  This last time I actually put this in a small casserole dish and it worked out even better becuase usually there is too much to fit into my quiche pan.

This was truly fantastic! I am actually eating it now for lunch the day after and the flavors propelled me to write a review. Couple changes: I added a container of shitake mushrooms instead of the canned mushrooms and used 3 shallots instead of the onion. After pouring in the egg mixture, I slightly moved the spinach around with a knife to facilitate the binding. I didn't stir the spinach, just poked and moved it to the side so the egg could seep in. :) This made for a more cohesive dish and one that did not feel like it was layered.

text:
I only had a 16oz package of spinach and decided to just use all of it along with an extra can of mushrooms. The outcome filled two 9in pie crusts. I only increased the amount of cheddar cheese by a half cup for topping both pies. I also only used a little over 1/3cup of butter for sautéing and doubled the egg mixture, though all of the egg mixture couldn’t fit. So in essence, I didn’t have to completely double the recipe to fill two 9in pie crusts. I’m glad I didn’t because it might have been too rich for our liking. We think it came out delicious! It's true, this recipe is very forgiving so if you want to add more of what you love (i.e. spinach) or add tomatoes like some other people have, it will still turn out great.

I wouldve given 5 stars but ingredients are way off!

text:
Easy to make.  Very similar to another quiche recipe on this site (can't remember it's exact name).  To cut down on fat/calories, I didn't use a pie crust.  Believe it or not, Rainbow Foods, a large grocer in my area, did not have the frozen chopped spinch.  It did, however, have frozen cut-leaf spinach so I got that.  I also used fresh mushrooms and just dumped some in since I like them.  I had a 4 oz- pkg of herb/garlic feta and then added 1/2 container of plain feta.  I used a Cheddar blend shredded cheese.  It baked up very well.  Didn't seem greasy as others have commented but I was surprised by the amount of butter for sauteing the onion and garlic.  I will try to cut down on that in the future.

city:

country:
None
text:
This is the best recipe...my first quiche. I did listen to reviews, used 2T. butter, 2 cloves garlic, a couple of diced button mushrooms cooked near the end with the onions and garlic, and 3/4 cup milk...perfect! I didn't need quite all of the cheese on top and used an Orononoque Orchards deep dish prepared frozen pie crust. I added 2T of julienned sun-dried tomatoes from a jar cut up fine. I thaw my spinach a bit and then leave it overnight in a sieve over a bowl to drain and then squeeze out the excess water in a towel before using. This was my first quiche and it was awesome! Friends at work loved it. It freezes very well and is great reheated in the oven. The crust even stayed crispy. For new cooks (and I am not a new cook)...PLEASE, put a cookie sheet under the frozen pie crust when you cook the quiche or you will have happen what just happened to me when I made it the second time....it bent in half over my oven door when I went to put it back in the oven after 15 mins!!!! What a mess. I should have known better. Also, don't be afraid to use whatever cheeses you have for the cheddar. For half of it I used a four cheese shredded blend that I already had and then the other half was sharp. You must use some sharp for flavor I think. Make this...your family or friends or just you if you are trying to make ahead some meals will just love it. After thawing pie crust for 15 mins, brush pie crust w/egg wash and cook 7 mins.for crispy crust. Annalou18 helped me. Thanks!

This was my first time making a quiche from scratch and it was delish! Followed the recipe making a few small changes - used only 1/4 c. butter, tomato and basil feta, and a Mexican cheese blend. Leftovers were good, albeit a bit soggy, but that was to be expected. Really yummy dish with a side salad or soup. Thanks for submitting!

text:
I made this for dinner tonight and my family and I loved it! I did make a few chanages. here we go: 1) I used fresh spinach, 2)i didnt have mushrooms so I used some sundried tomatoes that i had marinated, 3) I only had Bulgarian feta, so I added some sumac (i remembered that in egypt and syria its added to spinach pies), 4) i browned some beef bacon and tossed that into the saute as well, along with a little of the rendered fat. 5) I reduced the milk to 3/4C. 6) I only added a dash of salt to the eggs before i whisked them. OK I admit it... i used all of the butter! those last 2T looked so lonely on the counter, I felt bad (hahahaha) anyway, this is a really easy recipe and takes no real tending, so I could see whipping up one of these on a weeknight again for sure, i will try it with less butter next time (maybe), but i had to try the full fat version first!

The only reason this doesn't get a 5 is that the measurements are a bit off. I keep everything the same except the eggs, add 2-3 more then the recipe calls for and you will have 2 quiches.  I also have used these ingredients, minus the egg and milk in veggie stromboli - delish!

Display Name:
MorganDavis

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Less egg and more cheese than your average quiche, which is a very good thing. I always adapt recipes, so I cut the milk and crust (inessential), doubled the garlic, used fresh spinach & mushrooms, and added artichoke hearts. As I was preparing this for a brunch we were throwing, my husband assured me that he didn't like quiche and would stick to the chocolate chip pancakes, thank you very much. Then he tried a piece to be nice and almost passed out! And I quote..."This is the BEST breakfast food I've ever eaten. Can we eat this all the time?" : ) It does have a lot of butter (that's why it's so yummy!), but it's so rich I think it's quite easy to feel satisfied eating a reasonable piece. It will last for several meals! Just serve a piece with some carbohydrates (croissants, biscuits, pancakes, waffles, etc.) or a salad so folks can fill up with some less rich food.   Oh, our guests loved it too! Everyone said, "REALLY good quiche." and "What did you do to this?!" with notes of surprise that were entirely satisfying. I will definitely make this again!

This is very good!  I followed the directions exactly as written; however, as others have noted, I only used half of the egg & milk mixture.  It also browned too quickly so I covered it with foil for the last 10 minutes and only baked it 28 minutes after the cheese was added.

text:
I did something different to the butter--heating over medium heat until brown and screening it off with cheesecloth. Then add back the brown butter into sauteed onions and spinach mix. The result is amazing, I'm guessing that's what the large amount of butter is for. Also I used 1/2 cup of evaporated milk instead.

This review is mostly based on the response I got from the women in my church group.  They all raved about the flavor.  The only change I made was that I cut down the butter to two tablespoons.  I would have given this five stars but there was too much egg/milk mixture.  I filled the deep dish pie crust until full and I still had plenty left over.  It made a mess while baking.  Good thing I had it on a cookie sheet.  Overall this is a great recipe and I'm adding it to my recipe box.

text:
Excellent recipe - my brunch guests loved it.  This is my first quiche, and I am so glad that I used this recipe.  I used two regular pie crusts, pre-baked them, divided the spinach mixture into each one, and poured the egg mixture equally on top of each one.    I did drain the spinach and mushrooms very well, pressing them against paper towels.  The only deviation was to use 1.5TB of butter. I will be making this again.
