text:
Quiche has been our Christmas morning tradition for years, and after this year, this recipe will be the only one I ever use!  It is definitely the best quiche I have ever had in my life.  Following the advice of commenters before me, I altered the recipe to suit my tastes and what I had on hand.  Instead of mushrooms I used canned artichoke hearts and some red bell pepper.  I had 2 frozen pie shells on hand, so I baked them ahead of time to make sure they stayed crispy, and I used both because this recipe makes a lot of filling.  (Even after dividing the filling between two pie shells, I couldn't fit more than 3 eggs on top of each.)  This was not only easy and quick to prepare, but also very delicious.  YUM!

text:
I did as another reviewer recommended; and doubled the eggs; and divided the rest between two pie pans.  Added fresh (saute'd) mushrooms instead of canned ones, didn't use feta (personal taste; used cheddar instead in chunks; and colby on top) and added some brocolli and spring onion too (had excess int he garden, and the kids like brocoli; but they don't like spinach; trying to come even a bit; we love spinach; grow it, kids don't like it at all); and fresh baby spinach leaves.  We loved it; but failed on the kids level... ohh, well, gotta cook something for us adults sometimes; too!  Thanks for the recipe; will use it again and again... perhaps trying different ingredients to get the kids to like them too; as it's a great way to use up excess eggs (as we get plenty; both duck and chicken; get about 8 eggs a day at the moment for a family of four...  always looking for ways to use them up, and this fits the ticket wonderfully!)

text:
I made some changes. I added a 12oz package of bacon. Used a little bit of the bacon grease to fry the onion and garlic. I don't like mushrooms or feta cheese so I just didn't add them. I didn't add any cheese to the spinach mix but I did add a little of the bacon. I put some of the cheese and bacon into the egg mix. I put the rest of the bacon in the bottom of the pie crust then some cheese. I put the spinach next with the last of the cheese and then the egg mix. I don't usually like quiche and this was great.

I should've read the most useful reviews! I used this recipe with the "Butter Flaky Pie Crust" from this site, and it was too much for my regular pie plate. This was pretty tasty, but it definately makes enough for two quiches! I didn't have another pie crust,  so I just put the rest of the filling and eggs and milk into a pie plate and it still turned out tasty without a crust. I used regular feta, fresh mushrooms, and colby instead of cheddar because this is what I had on hand, and the flavors worked well. Thanks for the recipe because u needed a recipe ibcould through together in a pinch with what I had on hand. This way we had leftover to to eat for breakfast in the morning. Made this for dinner and also served with salad and bread on the side. Perfect!

Display Name:
misscdb

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this today for lunch with a friend. It was my first time making a quiche. I pricked and baked the pie shells for 8-9 mins. Then, as a friend suggested, I spread some mustard on the crust before adding the egg mixture. I omitted the butter, cooking fresh spinach, with garlic and onion, in a little olive oil. Then I drained the mixture before adding it to egg mixture. I also cut back the milk to between 1/2 and 2/3 of a cup. I used canned, condensed milk in this recipe. I used regular feta cheese. I added more cheddar to the mixture and less for a topping.I waited about 20 mins into cooking to add the top cheddar. This recipe made two quiches. Even though the oven is a very good one, my quiches required an extra 5-10 mins cook time. It came out perfect!! I served it with a greek salad w/ greek vinagrette. Thanks for the recipe! I will definitely be making this one again:)

text:
Amazing taste. I did precook the crust for about 6 minutes, as someone else suggested. I also used less cheddar.  This did make too much for one quiche so I put all of the spinach/cheese mix in the crust & poked a few holes in it so the egg would get in. Then I poured as much of the egg mix in that would fit & tossed the rest. Next time I will probably make 1/2 the egg mix. Everyone loved it and they commented how much more they liked it than other quiches BECAUSE it was not eggy. One person who didn't like quiche said it was the first thing she ate.

text:
I used 10oz. of chopped, thawed broccoli instead of spinach, half a 10oz. package of fresh mushrooms chopped and only used about 3oz. of feta since that's all I had on hand. I didn't put the cheeses in the cooking pan for fear of it melting and creating a tougher mess to clean up. I put the veggies in the pie crust, sprinkled with the cheeses and then covered with the egg mixture. Used the easy No Fail Pie Crust III. Turned out great!

Display Name:
beatnavy

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Loved it - Used this healthier variation/substitution:

Substitutions:
2T butter instead of 1/2 cup (for saute)
Fresh Spinach 10oz instead of frozen
1/2 onion instead of full
no garlic
Lactaid instead of milk (made it lighter)
A little more garlic herbed feta (softer garlic taste - more cheese)
Reduced fat italian mixed cheeses instead of cheddar
Tomato sliced placed on top instead of muchrooms.

Preparation Changes:
- Melt the 2T butter in a skillet, saute the onion on one side as you saute down the spinach.  As the onion starts to turn golden, mix the two together.  salt/pepper to taste.  Remove from the burner to cool long enough for you to get the cheese ready.  Quickly mix together and then spoon into the pie crust.  Then follow the rest of the recipe.

Thanks to the original author because it's the best recipe I've used.

Wow, yum yum good!  Great flavors!  The first time I made this I used heavy cream instead of milk and it was awesome.  The second time I used milk like you are suppose to and it was still awesome!  I always end up having too much milk/eggs so I have started cutting the amount of milk and eggs in half and that works really well.  This is a great dish to make and then stick in the fridge and reheat later...I personally think it's best that way.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was REALLY GOOD. I had to give 4 stars because it's a GOOD THING that pie crusts come in 2 packs, LOL! This made so much filling that I had to grab the spare shell from the freezer, and scoop half the filling from the other, overflowing, shell.   In order to get the 2 shells nice and full, I added in an extra egg each.  The only other thing I changed was adding a little bell pepper and fresh seeded tomato to make up for no mushrooms (I hate mushrooms). I cooked the peppers with the onion and garlic, and added the tomatoes right before the egg (so they wouldn't disintegrate). Everyone loved it, which is saying something coming from my veggi-phobic family. And yes. I definitely used deep dish crusts ...

text:
Very very good. There was too much butter in the recipe for my liking so I used only 1/4 cup. I added an extra egg and used skim milk...it set perfectly. I also used 7-8 ounces of fresh mushrooms and cooked them with the garlic and onion until soft before adding the spinach. As someone suggested before I cooked the pie crust for about 8 minutes before adding the filling to prevent a soggy bottom. This quiche was the best quiche I've ever made.

This was ok.  I thought it could use a little more egg & cheese but a little less spinach.  I did pre-bake the crust. You must dock the crust (prick it all over the bottom with a fork) to keep it from puffing up.  
Next time I'll try 6 eggs and I'll mix the cooled spinach & mushrooms with the eggs & milk before I pour into the deep dish pie plate.

I made it for brunch on Easter and got rave reviews from my family. The only changes I made were the following (just to make it a little healthier and more flavorful): --I used a whole-wheat pie crust (from Whole Foods) --olive oil instead of butter for the sauteed onions --fresh mushrooms instead of canned which I sauteed along with the onions. I will definitely be making this again! Thanks, Bailey!

text:
This was excellent. It was a great success at our Christmas party. I did make a few changes. I didn't add mushrooms.  Ithawed out the frozen spinach over the stove (no water added). Once thawed I placed the spinach between paper towels and squeeae out the rest of the moisture.  auted onions and garlic in a little olive oil. Melted 1/4 cup of butter. Used cream instead of milk. Used a little italian seasons, because I didn't have flavored cheese.

This turned out beautiful.  It's important to make sure that you use a deep-dish pie crust, as a normal one would be thin enough to get soggy.  Make sure that you're spinach is really well-drained.  It was a little greasy the first time I made it, I think you can as much as half the amount of butter to help this.  A great meal served with fruit or waldorf salad!

text:
I made my own crust for this recipe and also substituted my preference for cheese. You can do both easily and it will still come out delicious. Really most cheeses will work for this recipe so, go with what you prefer or have on hand.
My only small criticism (not really criticism...more like preference)is that I thought it could use a little extra something. Something like chopped ham would taste lovely in this.
I'm going to try this next time!
Thanks for the awesome recipe!

text:
This recipe was somewhat of a disaster for me, but I'm giving it 3 stars based on its potential. When I put the filling into the pie crust, the spinach mixture nearly filled the entire crust. There was very little room for the egg mixture, and it ended up overflowing. I did follow the recipe and did use the 9-inch deep pie crust, so I'm wondering if the proportions are off. I'd make it again but next time use TWO pie crusts. The flavor was good, so I can see why it's getting good reviews. Seems like a lot of people are modifying the recipe using less butter and milk and fewer eggs so maybe I'll give that a try.

text:
Wow, my first time making a quiche, and it turned out "perfect" according to my boyfriend! What a good recipe. I halved all the ingredients to make a 9.5" regular quiche. I bought some refrigerated pie dough and first toasted it for 5 minutes in a glass pie pan. Left out the mushrooms(the bf doesn't eat them), so I added an extra ounce of feta. Also, I only used 1.5 tablespoons of butter. I mixed the shredded cheese in with everything else and just baked for 50 minutes. Next time, I'll experiment with bacon and etc. Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
I changed this recipe quite a bit, but I'm going to give the submitter credit as she did encourage us to do so.  I made my own pie crust using half white and half wholewheat flour, and I used fresh mushrooms.  I also used only three eggs, half a cup milk, and left out the extra butter and the cheddar cheese (because I didn't have any).  I had been hesitant to try my hand at quiche up until now but it was a great success.  My boyfriend said that it was the best quiche he'd ever tasted, and we live in France so we've tasted quite a few.

I've never made quiche before, so was looking for a guideline. This was great! I used a lot less butter, as others have commented on, and omitted the mushrooms. I added some paper-thin sliced julienned ham. Next time I will use less cheese - it was a little much for my husband's taste. Also, I missed the "deep dish" note on the pie and used a regular pie shell - only need half the eggs and milk. All in all - a keeper.
